content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								Let me qualify here, I like this game quite a bit and I think it does deserve all the praise it recieved. So why the negative review? Well for one, Steam doesn't give me the option to have a neutral review, and two I want to give potential buyers some reasons as to why they wouldn't want to buy in. Most of the negative reviews don't really do that, at least not in detail.I've been following this game for a long time, a lot of love has gone in to its development, and it really shows through the quirky spritework. The problem with the development is that it's just been so painfully slow that I can't recommend spending $15 on it at this point, because the desire to check back in after a few months when nearly nothing new has been added fades away after over two years; and that's how long I've had this game. It was first released for beta purchase around April 1, 2014.Over the course of two years, the story has essentially gained one new dungeon (of which there was only one before) along with a marginal amount of content that shows this game is going to be in development for many more years. The content that's there is good, sure, but it's not so stellar as to justify playing through the story more than once or twice.The real mode that seems to add playtime to this game is its arcade mode, which is roguelike in nature, and requires a good understanding of enemy/boss patterns to do well in. Players play through two floors representing each area in the story mode, complete with enemies from said area, and have no chances to heal except at the end of each floor. Despite having numerous floors and all of the enemies from the story mode, it's pretty light on content in terms of roguelikes. There are unlockables and such, but they only give minor advantages, and as a result adding more floors to the mode seems kind of pointless in its current state. Even after over two years of going back to this game I struggle to reach the 7th floor of what must be over 14 at this point. There isn't much incentive to bother trying to reach those floors either. So should you buy this game? Well that depends on how patient you are. After two years I'm pretty burned out and don't see myself playing this game for a long, long time. If you think you can wait for what could be 5 years to play a finished product and want to support the developers, then by all means get this game. If not, keep an eye on it and pick it up a few years down the road when it has a more justifiable amount of content to offer.Edit: Thanks for all the support guys, since this review got so much attention I want to add a little more. If you're worried about spending $15 on a game that won't be finished, don't be. This game is a safe buy in my opinion. Even though the development has been very slow, it has been extremely consistent and the team behind this game definitely has what it takes to finish the job. Secrets of Grindea has been in the works since 2011, and the quality of the content in it has only improved since. Their dev blog[www.secretsofgrindea.com] has a weekly recap that is posted nearly every week without missing a beat. So if you're interested, definitely keep an eye on this game, because it is one of the better early access titles out there, despite the slow development speed.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Where to begin.  This game is as advertised.  It's a game similar to Secret of Mana (SNES), Crystalis (NES), Zelda-esque, Final Fantasy Adventure (Original GB)  and many other old RP games.You can customize your character physically by gender, colour of your clothes, hair style and colour, and name.  Additonally, you get a vanity part for your hat, face, weapon, and shield.The gameplay is very nice, you can be a full warrior, full mage, whatever you want to be; a combination if you want.  Although, being a healer is not an option.This is a beta game, it's not complete, from my estimation it's a little near half done, if that.You can play cooperatively, over the internet, using your steam friends list or direct IP!  This is awesome!You grind in the game, if that wasn't obvious.  (What old school console RPG didn't have you grind?  It's part of the fun!)The transition between keyboard and controller playing is seamless, you just start using your keyboard and it swaps to keyboard mode, you use your controller, it swaps to controller mode.  I found this particularly great!The host of the game's save file is progressed in the story, however - if you're not the host - you keep everything you gained.  You simply have to play through the story (by hosting or single player) to go through it.  The rewards though, you do not acquire again, you already have them!  :DThis is an awesome game!  As far as I'm aware only three people are working on it and they're from Sweden.  They have me as a fan.  The sprite animation is awesome, the artwork for the avatars is great and expresses much emotion, and the game looks very polished for a beta that is not even half done!I used to pay $50+ US dollars for games like these, and wait years for the next to come out.  I love the game very much, and I haven't even started exploring the Arcade Mode.tl;dr - Buy this game if you loved Secret of Mana or any similar games on the console or PC.  Especially if you want to play it co-op with friends over the internet!

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								To review this game is to review it in two parts.Story Mode: An amazing adventure akin to the days of Secret of Mana, Sword of Mana and Seiken Densetsu 3. Quick swordplay with an oldschool-meets-polish aesthetic that's filled with charm. Combat is quick paced and - with over 20 skills and spells with multiple charge levels, along with 30 talents - more or less unique for every character made. Every attack, skill and spell feels as if it has weight behind it for a thoroughly satisfying brawl through hordes of monsters and challenging bosses.The story is serious at times, tongue in cheek in others without outright resorting to cheese. There's plenty of side-quests, mini-games and collectables, but contrary to the name no grinding appears to be necessary. The shield is as relevant to the gameplay as the sword is, every attack can be blocked if you know the exact timing, reminding me of the days of 'Timed Hits' from Super Mario RPG and Final Fantasy 8.The music is beautiful, the characters well written to make you love or hate them, I can't say enough good things about Story Mode. The only shame is it's incomplete, but between pet taming, treasure hunting, fishing, card collecting, playing with 4 player online co-op and duking it out in the arena, there's more than enough content to keep me busy between updates.Arcade Mode: All the rules from Story Mode no longer apply, Arcade Mode feels like an entirely different game. Less Secret of Mana, more Binding of Isaac. You start in an empty plain and delve within a randomized roguelike-esque labyrinth. Each room is different every time, filled with traps and all manners of enemies or bosses not present in Story Mode. HP is precious, mastery of skills, spells and shielding is required.Arcade Mode is perfect for sinking endless hours into as you try to go deeper and deeper into the labyrinth, gaining points and essence to level up and expand your town, unlock new NPCs to aid you, take on quests for rare and unique loot not found anywhere else. Skills and spells are best experimented with in here to see which build suits you best. With friends it's harder, but with 4 people on screen the monsters barely stand a chance once you hit your groove. The online leaderboards for Arcade Mode help to give it even more replay value by trying to do better than your friends or complete strangers to try and hit #1.If you have any doubts whatsoever, try the demo. With an hour of Story Mode gameplay, several hours of Arcade Mode and co-op bundled into the demo, it's a great teaser for what to expect moving forward.Tip: Opt into 'Frontline' by selecting SoG in your library if you want quicker updates. The normal version receives slower updates, but your experience in the game will be much smoother.

content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
Early Access Review
This review is based on the game in its current state at the time of posting and is completely my opinion. Yours may differ to mine. I also only really played the story mode and did co-op.Secrets of Grindea is an action RPG with a major focus on the story and meticulous detail worked into its environments and graphics.I just completed everything in the Secrets of Grindea that is currently available in the version out at this time and I have to say that what they have so far is fan-bloody-tastic.Things I liked Fantastic pixel graphics with fluid animations that make me say "wow" in some circumstances An interesting story with creative sidequests and lovely characters Hats and lots of them. I'm a Team Fortress 2 man and I found the choice of hats to be most adequate. The plethora of references. I won't spoil any of them, but they're there. The soundtrack consisted of fantastic tracks that all matched their locations in game. Not a single track sounded out of place in this game.Things I didn't like all that much The story was a bit short. But that can be attributed to the fact that it's in early access. The limited supply of weapons available was quite disheartening as I found myself wielding the most powerful one-handed sword in the game about 1/2 of the way through the story with not much choice on what else to use. Player customzation is unfortunately incredibly limited with the only changable things being colour of clothing, hair style, hats, and facewear. I found myself yearning for a dress but was sadly stuck with my adventurers outfit. I don't want efficieny, damn it, I want to look fabulous!Overall after I played through and 100% completed the game with a mate of mine we both left with a feeling of satisfaction and the desire to one day return to Grindea when more content is released. What I'm trying to say is buy the game already. It's worth it.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								Let me start off by saying if you think this game doesn't have grinding in it...then seek help. There are people who care about you and don't wish to see you go down this path (not me per se, we've only just met. But I'm sure there are people who love you very much. Like your grandmother or that neighbor with the nice rack. Anyway, I'm going off topic here).Secrets of Grindea is a tongue-in-cheek RPG that draws heavily on the nostalgia of games like Secrets of Mana, Zelda: Link to the Past, and Illusion of Gaia. The sprite animations and colorful backgrounds mimic classic 16-bit games and go well with the fluidity of combat. NPCs are prevalent in towns and in the overworld to the point where the world does not feel empty and that their character is not some lone warrior living on a planet full of monsters (though that sounds like an awesome game idea. Dibs). Each area has its own unique feel that you will hopefully enjoy because the aforementioned grinding will have you staying in one area killing the same enemies for drops.The combat is extremely straight forward where your basic attack is spamming one button or having a charged skill where you hold and release one button. Let me go on record to say that I do not think this is a bad thing. Sure, you won't be chaining attacks that culminate in your wooden sword hitting with the power of a tactical nuclear device, but you will be unlocking and upgrading skills that define the way you, the player, wish to play. The skills are limited (for now I hope) to a 1 handed skill set, 2 handed skill set, and a magic skill set. The player is able to mix and match these skills however he or she wants and has the option to refund some or all of the skill points that were spent by spending gold (this is done in the menu rather than with an NPC). There is a bow the player can get from a sidequest but so far doesn't have a dedicated set of skills to leveling up the damage.The story is pretty straightforward for an RPG of the era it emulates: You are a guy or gal that wakes up, is handing a magical bag that can hold anything without weight restrictions and are sent out to become a renowned member of the "Collectors". It seems, from the start, that these "Collectors" are a bunch of people that go out and collect cool, rare things. It is all very prestigious. And dangerous. And sexy. Seriously, so far every NPC that isn't a Collector is jealous of you. Normally one would have to buy seven sports cars and have an attractive life mate to get that kind of recognition. This game hands that to you right off the bat (Disclaimer: The developers of this game will NOT buy you cars nor introduce you to hot people for a hook up).My main concern with the game is that it seems too short and I say that knowing full well that not all the features in the game have been implemented; this is not the reason that I feel the game is too short. The in-game journal keeps a record of all the enemies in the game and what they drop when killed. Enemies you haven't killed yet appear in the journal as silhouettes. Upon counting (yes, I did a math) I found that there are only about thirty (30) enemies total in the game including boss enemies. This, in my opinion, is a low number which may make gamers shy away from the game. An increase in not just the number of potential enemies but different types of enemies will add more variety to the grinding while still keeping the player's interest high. I eagerly await the areas that have not yet been implemented to the game.Now, I'm not going to end this review by giving the game a number based off of 5 nor 10 nor 325745456415 (<--- not sure what this number is. It just punched my Numpad to come up with something ridiculous). I will end this review with just a few simple words:I enjoy this game.I hope you enjoy it too.Still enjoying the game after so long.

content:
Posted: March 27
Early Access Review
								It seems that a lot of the top reviews have forgotten something important from the devs:  “Please read all the Early Access info before buying!”  So, before you read any reviews,  please  read that EA description.Back? Alright. The Concerns The main concerns I’ve seen from top commenters are amount of content and update frequency. Interestingly enough, the devs address both. First, content. Many complaints tend to stem from the fact that, if you skip cutscenes and side missions, there’s about four hours of content, and their disappointment at its limited playtime, etc. However, the developers noted this in the EA info: “it takes about 4 hours to complete if you skip most of the side content. If you want to do everything currently in Story Mode, expect to invest at least 10 hours.” Does this mean you should buy the game immediately? No. It just makes those complaints about content seem a little less grounded when they were given warning. Next, update frequency. This seems to be the major complaint with most Not Recommended reviews. Surprise surprise, the devs were prepared again.  “If frequent updates and/or a determinable release date is very important to you, we advise you to wait for the finished product!”  Again, those complaints lose a little luster once it’s clear that there was a warning. With a large development team, big and detailed games can take years. This game is being made by three people. It’s going to take a long time. However, as of today on day of writing, March 27, 2017, the devs posted an update that ends the area that will be the largest until the game’s very end, which means the update frequency should increase. (Sidenote: I don’t blame reviewers for not knowing that. I only learned it existed twenty minutes ago. But, it is important to note.) In any case, the update frequency is pretty good for three people on this intensive of a game. With that out of the way, let’s move to: The Gameplay This is the star of the game. The swing arcs are clearly defined for each weapon, the animations are smooth, it feels good to hit enemies, with enemy recoil and appropriate sound effects, and a wide variety of character expansion options. In Grindea, there is no class system. When you level up, you receive points that you can put into skills, spells, and stat bonuses of your choice. Want to be a brutal tank who crushes their enemies? Do it. Want to be a deadly mage who roasts and electrocutes their opponents from afar? Do it. Want to be a glass cannon who can crit 25% of the time for 165% of their damage? Do it. That’s where the replayability comes from: a wide variety of combat options and stat choices. I personally have all nine character slots filled with hard-hitting tanks and long-range mages and spellswords and summoners and so on. There are even a couple support spells, with more planned for implementation. You can also get a pet by taming some of the common enemies in the game. You can feed them, and they’ll give you stat bonuses if you put enough into one stat.  Grindea is also very playable with a controller, and I recommend it. While keyboard is good, a controller hearkens back to SNES-era RPG’s and feels great. This game also doesn’t want you to grind. Yes, it’s in the name. That’s the joke. The more you try to farm in this game, the more enemies that appear. You can get overwhelmed if you aren’t careful. The Story I honestly love this game’s story. While the core plot is pretty simple, get some things so the world doesn’t explode, it’s really the characters that make Grindea feel alive. Every character’s text box portraits are detailed and have multiple expressions. Their in-game sprites look good and have smooth animation. These animations give personality to the characters and distinguish them from “blue-haired dude” and “is that Cloud?” There’s growth and blooming relationships between characters. Even with the protagonist, I was pleasantly surprised. Rather than being The Great Hero of the Ancient Prophecy, you’re just a kid doing their job as a Collector, like a lot of other people. You fall into having to save the world rather than being born as the Savior of the Earth or Whatever. You end up “borrowing” some Really Old Super Dangerous and Powerful Artifacts not because a legend told you to, nor because you woke up and decided to, nor because your dead parent spoke to you in a dream or whatever. You just end up having to save the world. There’s charm, wit, humor, and no end of pun names. Singleplayer vs. Multiplayer There are arguments for both sides of this. While singleplayer is viable and the same experience, you’re just not as strong as with others. Some bosses are very tough without help.  Looking at you, Seasons Hydra.  With friends that also enjoy this genre, Grindea is excellent. As long as everyone has a half-decent router and a computer that meets the minimum on the store page, you probably won’t have issues. While large areas do take a while to load on less superb computers, it’s nothing unbearable. Unless  someone’s  ping is 30,000. So, if you’re playing this alone, it’s still fun, but you’re going to have to work harder and longer than with others simply because more people make the game easier. The Verdict If you want a finished game, don’t buy this. If you want a perfectly polished game, don’t buy this. If you want a game that absolutely positively has no bugs, don’t buy this. If what I and the store page have told you has you itching to buy this, buy it. It’s a lot of fun and a good game. If you’re on the fence, pick up the demo. It’ll give you a better sense of gameplay than words ever could. I came into this Early Access game expecting just that. I was pleasantly surprised.  I recommend this game for stellar characters, graphics, animations, music, and mechanics. It’s not finished, certainly. It takes time to make a game, certainly. There are issues, certainly. But what’s there is good. Just because it’s slow doesn’t make it bad.

Posted: November 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Story-wise, it's nothing special. The story is well-written, funny at times, but ultimately nothing that will win any prizes. Action-wise, it's nothing special. Combat systems and skill trees reminiscient of soo many other games of the same kind.Visuals are not really anything special either. Everything is cute and well-made, like in so many other games of the same kind.But you know what? It's engaging, it's fast-paced, it's completely glitch-free and smooth, and most importantly it supports multiplayer through Steam. It's both a relaxing and fast-paced Action RPG that I can definitely recommend that you enjoy with a friend or two. Not to mention it is still in Early Access, which means there's lots of content to still come.So far, this game is extremely well-made and polished, and definitely something you can sink some time into, alone or not; though the multiplayer aspect was ultimately what made me buy it. I haven't tried the arcade mode yet, but I already feel I've seen enough of this game to recommend it dearly.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								This game has driven me to make my first serious review about a game, ever. This game is one of the most satisfying RPG experiences I have ever had, ranking above many AAA games. Everything about this game brings about an intense craving to  play more  in the best possible way. Pros: Combat -Large skill tree filled with unique and interesting abilities.-If you like an ability you can level it up over time to make that ability do more awesome stuff-The freedom to mix melee / ranged spells to create a unique playstyle-Epic and highly original bosses that are frequent and challenging The Story and Regions -Colorful and vibrant art style with very well done sound effects-Likeable characters and lighthearted approach make for an enjoyable story with a mysterious undertone-Main quests take you to several areas that are have their own unique themes and enemies-Regions are fairly large with explorable secrets and puzzles containing hidden loot Loot and Cards -The everpresent chance of obtaining "cards" is one that creates the urge to grind each area's different enemies-Not only do enemies drop cards they drop crafting materials as well as rare and unique equipable gear to further create incentive to grind  THE DEVS! -The trio over at Pixel Ferrets are incredibly talented and hard working-Weekly dev blog updates along with frequent patches add tons of content at a high rate-Buy them coffee to add hyperspeed perk to your favorite dev teamOther Pros:-Easy to connect multiplayer supporting up to 4 people-Well done controller support-A talking bag that roasts peopleCons: -Smallish amount of craftable material (But of course more will be added over time)-Some bosses are way harder than others on the hard difficulty (perhaps need more difficulty settings?)As an early access review the full potential of this game has yet to be realized however; this game has so much personality, tied with a fun combat system and an enjoyable playthrough experience making for a game that has a lot to give.This game is growing fast so you'll always be able to come back and enjoy more of the world of Grindea!I would highly reccommend that you purchase this game if you love RPG's because this RPG is every gamers wet dream.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								To start... I'm on the fence about this one. If steam offered a "maybe" option, I'd pick that.  It was number one on my wishlist for a long time. A LONG TIME. Having a baby this summer, so prob not gonna be able to play much games when that happens, plus the development is taking centuries on this one, so I figured I might as well enjoy what I can out of this game now since it might not happen later.The Good: The game sings of polish and love. What is done is fantastic. It looks simply amazing and you can tell there has been a lot of talent and devotion put into what is playable. The gameplay is freaking awesome. So much diversity, so many options for builds. You can go pure range caster, you can go one handed dps build, or put points into heaving hitting two handed skills that'll take a quarter of a bosses hp down in one well timed hit. There's a lot of choice. And you can also respec at a hefty in game currency price for those who like that option. The gameplay is a 10/10. Really ace. Most pickups are shown aesthetically on your character. The hats (which is arguably the most viewable part of your character over boots and armor since your head is huge) are viewable, while the chest pieces and boots are not. It's basically just headwear and weapons. You also have the option to have "style items" which are items that always show regardless of what you have equipped. Like the witch hat look? Equip it in style, and put a better stat hat to boost you. Replayability: It's definitely there. I'll likely replay the story mode several times at least, just to try different builds. One handed, two handed, caster, etc. It'll be fun. The Not Nearly As Good: For having been in development for many years, really, like five years, I was both surprised and disappointed at the scarcity of actual content. There are only a handful of quests. There is a laughable amount of items. For example, I went with a two hand warrior build my first playthough, and I counted five weapons. FIVE. I have all of them. And they all have the same attack animation. A swing arc in front. I was kind of picturing a little more... There are only a couple of areas in the game right now. I don't know how many more are planned but the game felt about half done progression wise to me. To give you an idea, you can fight your way across the entire map in about 15-20 minutes. The temples are cool, but they're short! The first took me maybe 30 minutes. The second, took about 30-40. And that's it. There's two temples. I looked for side quests of which there are many, but they're short too.  For how long the temples are, I was expecting ten of them. Nope. I think story mode took me about five hours in total and I got 72% on completion. Some of that was spent mindlessly farming for combat's sake and some more of that was spent in the arena doing the two challenges over and over to get them perfect.Arcade mode is another beast. I want to love it, but it honestly frustrates the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of me. It seems way unbalanced. It's basically a roguelite within the game. You start at level 0 and fight through small arena level maps called floors, to a boss, onto the next floor. And it's hard as balls. Hence the frustration. Take damage 3-4 times and your dead. There are NO HEALTH DROPS when fighting. You get a measly health orb when you beat the boss and progress onto the next floor, but honestly, I think the whole arcade mode just needs rebalancing, or a freaking difficulty mode option. Make it so enemies do less damage, or drop health orbs, whatever. I've played it for several hours and only gotten to floor 3 like twice. Out of what, 12? I'm frustrated when I play arcade mode. Not to mention the slow as turtle progression system associated with arcade mode. You get "essence" which you can spend to unlock perks to start arcade mode. For example you can buy the perk which unlocks a small metal sword to boost damage from 25 at start to 35. Great. Except it takes FOREVER to get the essence. They're not guaranteed drops and I maybe get one every 3-4 runs of arcade mode. And it costs ten to unlock the lowest perks? Then fifty for a second perk slot (so all your perk unlocks are useless because you can only bring one perk at a time until you unlock another perk slot) and 150 for the third and final. Good crap. This could be fixed by lowering perk costs, or guaranteeing drops based on point scores, but as of now, I could put 100 hours into the arcade mode alone before I unlocked another perk slot. Frustrating. Overall: Like I said in the beginning, I'm really torn. I absolutely adore the combat and look of this game. It's amazing. I just wish there was more of it. It really only wet my whistle. I am left wanting. The arcade mode? I want to like it, but am left.... not liking it due to the current (albeit fixable) issues I see in it. I'll rate this up, but I really recommend just waiting for release... in 2020. Then you can play the entire game at once.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've been waiting for a game like this for YEARS.Zelda/ Ys meets Castlevania, with a story like something out of SNES-era JRPGs.Grindea doesn't take itself too seriously, but really hits home with amazing sprite animations, exeptionally tight and ballanced gameplay, a loot/crafting system that makes you actually want to collect things you don't need, and a simple, yet complex level up system that honestly doesn't feel like any I've seen before, and to top it off, it's got a killer hard mode (arcade mode) that reminds me why I suck at rouguelikes, yet for some reason keep coming back to them!Oh, AND it's got a great coop system! My gf and I look for fun coop games pretty frequently, and we're often dissapointed. Not this time! Great weekend gaming/ veg session!The only gripe I have, is that since it's early access, the adventure content is incomplete. It took the two of us about 14 hours to "complete" the story at 100%. Arcade mode had more stuff, but was a little too punshing for us to experiment much.  I need the rest of that story!Seriously. Buy this game. At full price.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								I like the game, it's really fun but for the amount of time it's taking them to finish it, it's not worth purchasing at this point. I bought this game nearly a year ago and it had about 5 hours of content, 3 of those hours were spent doing side quests and grinding items... the other 2 hours were the main quest... not a whole lot going on for it right now.If you started the game over from scratch, you could probably squeeze about 15 hours in right now, and that's grinding out all the items enemies drop, including their cards and doing all the sides quests, including fishing. There's currently two dungeons available which looks to be about 40% of the game.Once the game is completely finished I'll do a proper review of it but until that time, I recommend everyone stay away from it, don't give dev's money they haven't rightfully earned yet... This game has been in production for too long and I think we as the consumers and fans need to see better results and more content before any more revenue is earned.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is what I've been missing since the advent of the Nintendo 64 and Playstation.  A quality, amusing, fun, multiplayer RPG that lets you be who you want to be and play with your friends.  A lot of the game is simple enough to pick up, while other aspects seem frustratingly incomprehensible (at first).The Good:Can choose the colors of your character's clothes and hair to stand out from other playersCan change your character's hairstyle to stand out as wellCan not only equip masks to look different, but can equip a "style" for masks, weapons, and shields, to allow your character to look a certain way without sacrificing the stats on their gear.  Major props to the developers for that mechanic.Humor.  This game has plenty of it.Active developers who read their forums and respond to feedback.  They not only tell you what they're doing every week, they show images and animated gifs that prove it's not just hot air.Experience Cap - You can avoid outleveling your friends by hunting in areas that are beneath you, so you get money and items but no XP.Arcade Mode - A randomly generated series of rooms that let you play a character with your friends and work toward the development of a town.Puzzles - The Temple of Seasons especially.  The use of seasons to not only affect the monsters' abilities, but also affect what can be done with the room, is amazingly well done.  Some of the other puzzles (like the bells) require a little attention to detail to figure out.  includes puzzle-related humor as well.Fishing - Because fish!  Ok, because it's a free way to get pet food, and the time investment doesn't make it feel cheaty for the return.Pets! - Because pets!  They don't fight for you, but you can increase your stats by feeding your pets certain items/fish.  The more they level the more food it will take, so you may wish to devote specific pets to specific traits.The Not-so-Good:Characters only ever have one clothing style, regardless of colors.  Perhaps my character wants to run around in robes, while my brother's wants to run around in a martial arts outfit like the monks in Evergrind.  What if my friend's female character wants to wer a dress, impractical as they are for adventuring?  Male or female, you only get one (the same) set of clothes.Small development team - While not really a bad thing, it does make the updates take a lot longer.  I applaud their desire to keep with a stable core that isn't going to lose interest and disappear during a project, but at the same time I wish they could produce updates just a little faster.  The forums show multiple offers of assistance, which are politely declined.Arcade Mode - Every time you die, you start over at level 1.  This doesn't make for a "grind" as much as a monotonous loop of re-leveling and trying to get back to where you had been.  While being too weak in the story mode allows you to backtrack and level, or hunt cards, the Arcade Mode forces you to keep moving into progressively more dangerous territory, and one bad spawn can reset you to zero instead of just backing off and leveling some more.Equipment limitations - With a good drop on one of the bosses you can have one of the best 1-h weapons in the current release of the game, halfway into Story Mode.  Most caster gear is functionally limited until far into the second temple, while you can get great melee armor and weapons throughout.  Even buying all gear and dropping/crafting allarmors as of the end of the current release, some of the most useful caster gear was either available 1/3 of the way into the game (MP regen robes) or at the end of current content (temple loot/drops).Monster Cards - While I do believe they are awesome and useful, I feel the benefits they grant are so powerful in some cases that you become reliant on them, rather than simply empowered by them.  To change them now might require some major balance tweaks, but Bloomo and Pecko are the two that spring to mind.  Without them I stood little chance alone in the Temple of Seasons against the mini-boss, after XP slowed to a crawl.  It seems awkward relying on those to beat a few fights...  Later in the game, unless more high-HP boosting cards are added to balance tough fights, I could see them being less useful.  For now though, they're pretty much a necessity.Economy - It never really seems like you have to worry about money in this game.  By the time I stopped hunting all the cards and mob drops, I had enough money to raise my Jumpkin to level 10 purely off potions.  Buying anything else was like picking out pocket lint, for all the impact it made in my savings.I believe that the game has incredible potential, and is great fun as it stands now.  I've put in 41.2 hours as of the time of this writing, and most if it is in Story Mode.  I probably won't be gaining much on my play time until they release more, but I keep checking the devblog every week for updates.Pixel Ferrets, I salute your game.  Keep at it.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								So. I got this game because it was cheap, and looked kinda fun. Well, I was not really expecting to be too amused, the game looked kinda low Q and corny.6 hours later i nthe same sitting, I realized I had not eaten anything, nor had a bathroom break. Well, it was a little late.10/10 would sit in♥♥♥♥♥♥again.Now for a more serious review. This game is 15 bucks at the time of this review. I have spent 30 on games that were NOT EVEN CLOSE to as good. I mean, after 20 minutes the game is already throwing you into a deep and fun story. after an hour you have already laughed your♥♥♥♥♥off more than once, and the game does a damned good job of not taking itself to serious.For an "ARPG" with great elements from zelda, secrets of mana, and God knows what else lies ahead, it plays any RPG fan into a lifetime of fun. The game excessively reminds you it's about the grind that RPGs generally have, yet you don't feel underpowered at all when you rush through something. On the flip side - it forces you to go back and grind because you feel like you are missing something if you don't.Pros ---Great Storyline-HOURS of content in a tiny little package-Devs clearly care about the game because it gets constant attention-Has parodies of all types of games (no spoilers)-YOU CAN FISH-Side story is still amazing, even in alpha/Early Access stages-Character options are not limited. You can be a mage, tank, DPS, or all, or a mix of whatever. -YOU CAN FISH!-Fishing has rewards-Fish have a purpose-Fish have multiple purposes-Fishing is seriously fun in this game-FISH-I see a ton of replay valueCONS -----No timer letting you know you have been playing for 6 and a half friggin hours straight.-Seriously, I can't find any cons for this game, and that scares me.Overall, this game is amazing.Graphics - 9.5/10 - They are amazing, a great homage to classic gaming.Sound - 9/10 - Some sound effects are a bit overbearing at times, and if you drop the volume you miss out on the little effects.Music - 10/10 - Great score. The entire game has music that keeps you going. At no point did I dislike it a bit. I almost didn't even notice myself humming to it all the time.Gameplay - 10/10 - The gameplay is perfect. For it's genre and subs, it has all of the elements in the right place. PLUS you have so much freedom in character creation.Controls - 9/10 - Id give it a ten, but sometimes the placement of things feels a little off. May be a bit better after you get used to it more I guess. Nothing is actually bad about them, but personally I miss keys from time to time when I need to chain things together. Overall, this game has a solid and simple 9.75/10. I mena, just buy it. You wont regret it a bit. They creators have done an amazing job, and I can't wait till this game is complete, and a sequal is in the works.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								Absolutely fantastic. I mean that, Best $15 I've spent in a good while.This developer earned my appreciation in a lot of ways in just 30 minutes. First, There is a free demo of the game. You can actually see, first hand, whether the game is going to run properly on your machine without spending a dime. Second, The game warns you of an error that makes some pcs run fullscreen mode badly in the demo. I do not experience this error, I find that it runs perfectly in fullscreen on my (rather old) pc. But the fact that they make that apparent in the demo shows an amount of respect for your time and money that, as a games consumer, I'm well accustomed to not getting. Third, The actual content of the game:Take the 2D Zelda titles, Update the pixel art quality, Add in Diablo-inspired skill trees, but hold the class restrictions. Then add active blocking with a timing mechanic that makes a perfectly timed block benefit you in some way, Differently depending on the attack being blocked. Then vary the weapons, One handed weapons for a swift attacking mobile build, Two handed for a slower hard-hitter, passive buffs on weapons for builds with other sources of damage. Then add spells; Simple fireballs, ice spikes, and chain lightning for damage. Utility spells like haste and damage buffs, Summons to support you, Debuffs to slow or continually damage enemies, and (Being a game in beta) More to come.Then there are the little things:*Pressing a key on your keyboard will change the control prompts to keyboard keys, Pressing a button on your controller will turn them into controller versions. No need to fiddle around with the options, It's automatic.*Downloading the demo before buying the game completes some of the full download, Reducing the time the download takes and minimizing redundant data use. *Your save files from the demo will be carried over to the full game should you (And you should) Purchase it.*And a tongue-in-cheek sense of humor present throughout that amuses me while not taking me out of the experience.I look very much forward to this game's future development and eventual completion, and to whatever Pixel Ferrets decides to do after. With the clear high standard of quality and respect for their customers they display I have no doubt in my mind that it will satisfy.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2016
Early Access Review
======================================Secrets of Grindea (Read on for the full review!)======================================TL;DR:Secrets of Grindea is a fantastic homage to the golden age of RPGs with a lot of modern comforts mixed in. It is very much feature complete and well polished for a game in early access, and not just features relating to gameplay mechanics, but actual activities you can occupy your time with. Campaign, a roguelite arcade mode, and co-op make for a healthy bit of longevity. Presentation is great, with good graphics, animations, and sound.Pick it up!======================================Pros:+ Graphics: Clean sprites, animation, and backgrounds. Fun colorful palette.+ Audio: Music is nice, sound cues are all reasonably distinct, excluding skill sfx.+ Story: There's enough humor baked in to make it less pointless, albeit hit and miss.+ Grind: Permanent buffs through card collection, tons of items, skills, etc.+ Design: Satisfying level design, puzzles, dungeon length, progression, etc.+ Heart: Some definite love has been poured into this product.Cons:- Waiting: It's not finished, yet.- Balance: Some playstyles fare better than others, but that isn't to say they aren't viable.Neutral:± Binds: Controller binding slightly limited.======================================Introduction:Did you ever wish there was a game where you could just sit around and fish, collect, craft, fight, dungeon dive, level up, and more as you choose, with each element being satisfying, but ALSO you wanted it to be similar to games like The Oracle of Ages/Seasons in the Zelda series? Secrets of Grindea is for you! If you don't want the last aspect, go look at Stardew Valley.Gameplay:Gameplay in Secrets of Grindea is simple. Interaction and weapon/skill use are on separate keys. With a keyboard, skills can be rebinded to specific keys. With a controller, skills can be swapped out inside of specific binds, you can't change the binds for shield and weapon use. Essentially, you're either interacting with an NPC, moving around, or fighting with your weapon and skills of choice. The fun comes from how many ways there are to execute these actions.You can fish, which involves keeping a bar lined up over an icon, horizontally. It's relaxing, satisfying, and you can even fish up equipment from time to time! You can use ingredients and even previous armors and weapons to craft new armors and weapons. Talk to NPCs for fun, or quests (many of which reward skill or talent points.) Refight bosses with ease and convenience whenever you want. Fight mobs with specific spawn zones whenever you want. Respec your build and play a different way. Redo your hair and clothes, including colors. Progress in the campaign, solving puzzles and completing challenges to complete dungeons. Kill monsters and critters to try and complete your card collection, which grant permanent buffs. Capture specific critters/monsters as pets, which can be used to boost your stats. Amass wealth by selling drops you farm. Try your builds in the roguelite arcade mode. Play alone. Play with friends. Play with strangers.No matter who you are, I maintain there is something to like in Secrets of Grindea...Except those annoying bees.Graphics:Oh, did I mention you can do all of this while being immersed in a cute colorful world with gorgeous sprites, backgrounds, and simple fun animations? Because you totally can do that.The screenshots should speak for themselves.Audio:So the sound in Secrets of Grindea may be the one weak point of the game. That isn't to say it is terrible, but simply that the rest of the game is so good, it has a bit of trouble keeping up with its current implementation. You won't find yourself buried in 100 different sounds blurring together and deafening you like some games, but at the same time, the diversity of sound applied to skills and actions can be a bit unsatisfactory. If all the skills had more distinct, appealing, impactful sounds that gave them more individual identity, the game would feel a lot better, as your character would then be something more individual you can be more attached to as well. Now, all that said, you probably won't be muting the game or anything, and the music is nice, although you may end up muting that if you hang out in certain hubs a lot. On the other hand, I found myself muting the music less often than other games, because it is appropriately relaxing and/or fitting for the areas and situations they go with.Conclusion:Secrets of Grindea is an RPG about variety and freedom. Oldschool gamers, adults, kids, casuals, and hardcore players can all find something fun here. I recommend Secrets of Grindea at:Full price.2x Full Price.3x Full Price.Maybe even 4x Full Price.======================================This endorsement approved by The Reviewers' Union,providing better standards for reviews and reviewers.======================================

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								I hate grinding. I really do. But not in this game as the grinding is rewarding and the battle system is a lot of fun.YOU DON'T HAVE TO GRIND - BUT YOU'LL WANT TOSecrets of Grindea is a 2D Action-RPG with roots in the SNES-era ARPG games such as the Mana-series and Legend of Zelda. The battles are fast and the basics are quite easy to learn. You can't just button smash your way through though. The system is very much reliant on your skills and strategies, despite the fact that you can grind for levels to overpower yourself.The beauty of the game is that you don't have to grind an excessive amount of time, but often you'll want to. If you just want to enjoy the story and explore the world, you can advance fairly quickly through the story. Boss battles are often very tough if you're underleveled but with a correct strategy, they are very beatable without power grinding. You unlock new areas to explore by advancing the story and you are free to roam the areas you've unlocked. The enemies are visible on the map and they are all avoidable.A 2D SANDBOX WITH TON OF STUFF TO DOFor the completionists, there is a ton of optional things to do. There's fishing, potion-making, side-quests, secrets, puzzles, pet catching, pet leveling, arena-battles, crafting and a ton of mob drops that are hard to get. I myself have already spend at least 2 times more than my Steam play-time shows in this game, doing all the optional stuff. That was over a year ago when there wasn't this much new content in it yet. The leveling system is very nice since you get points to spend on skills as you please. There is a good amount of different skills to choose from and all of them have strategic value. There is also a lot of different equipment which you can buy, craft or get as a drop from the monsters.YOU DON'T PLAY POKEMON-GAMES FOR THEIR STORYThe story isn't awful either. It's not the focus of the game nor the main reason to buy the game. It has enough meat in it to keep you motivated to go further and to give some context to your adventure but don't expect it to move you to tears or grab you emotionally. Think Pokemon games and their story and you'll know what level of story-telling to expect.As a big fan of stories and powerful story-telling in games, I would've wanted a more compelling story-telling personally but because of the strong gameplay, the lack of PSX-era Final Fantasy-esque story telling doesn't bother me much at all.TOO LONG, DIDN'T READAll in all, this has been my #1 most anticipated indie-game since 2013, when I bought the pre-order beta. SoG is a a good balance of excellent gameplay, exploration and story. While the story is not up to par with the gameplay, the complete package is still excellent and the 3 Swedish Stooges can be proud of what they've been working on for all these years.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's a zelda-eqse play-with-your-friends 8 bit RPG + an additional mode where you can play it as a roguelike with your friends. It's incredibily polished and the combat system is well refined and requires more timing and depth than other games of the same genre. While some of the ways to beat the bosses are cliche, this is not necessarily a downside because they are splendidly executed. Furthermore, there are a fair amount of bosses whose patterns/attacks the developers have taken creative liberty to make unique, unexpected, and enjoyably difficult. Characters are not class bound; rather each character has a limited number of usuable skill points and the same pool of skills they can choose from. This allows for multiple unique playthroughs on both story and arcade (roguelike) mode. I haven't found a similar game that brings forth the amount of depth, polish and nostalgia that Grindea has.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you are looking for a game to evoke your memories of childhood, this is it.  Secrets of Mana was bar none my favorite game on the SNES.  Nothing I have played since gives quite the same feeling of grinding on rabites for hours on end to build weapon skills.Not only does Grindea have a similar battle system, but it adds several customization options, from combat skills to magic to costumes, it also adds puzzle elements and arcade modes for further challenge.  The rare loot drops keep you farming mobs and bosses, and for the meta meta minded, there are card drops from in game enemies, in game achievements, Steam achievements, and presumably down the road, Steam cards.  It's a total overload of gathering meta!If I had to pick some complaints about the game, here they are:Arcade mode - I'm not patient enough, and never get passed the first or second stage.  Gimme a heal, dammit.Greenlight - It took way too long to get Greenlight, dammit.Development time - Stalking the devblog gets old after a while.  It has been way too long a wait for the complete game, dammit.I might have an issue with patience.Do yourself a favor, if you ever enjoyed overhead Nintendo games, support the devs, give this a shot.  It's only an amazing themesong and a fuzzy sprite away from being a classic.Also, hats.  That is all.

								What I like in this game :- Cute arts, animations, sounds and musics (it's really well crafted and lots of tiny details)- Cute story (not finished yet, but the beginning is nice)- Fishing mini game- Pet collecting- Card collecting that gives you character stats- Customisable character, with vanity slots for armors and weapon just for look !- Skill system (I haven't played enought yet to judje it indepth, but just to play casually for the moment, it's simple and gives you a lots of choices to  build up differently your character)- Grinding ! It helps a lot with the grinding point too !)- multiplayer : easy to host or join a game. Just becarefull of the ping :p- Arcade mode : addictive and hard !What I don't like :-What I would love to see in the game :- Housing ! I found some housing item so I guess that will come.. maybe ? :D- more mini games !Yeah there is nothing in the "what I don't like" list, it's normal. It's an awesome game !If you are wondering if buying an ARPG in early access is worth it, this one is really worth it.Go buy it !Right now.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								I have over 100 hours pumped into the game [if you include the pre-steam access] and this is one of my favorite games of all time.Pros:- Typical story, but hilarious dialog, fun characters and environmental/discovery-based story telling makes it a great experience.- Super deep and rewarding combat system with a plethora of skills and mechanics to master such as the perfect guard.- Enemies and bosses attack differently between normal and hard mode, as well as single or multiplayer- Skill charging makes it so you have almost 3 different skills at your disposal despite leveling only one skill.- Loads of side quests, mini games and discoveries to be found.- Multiplayer with up to 4 players that is super smooth gameplay-wise. Connection is also easy via Steam friend list.- Gorgeous pixel art that contains many little details to make the game world feel alive.- Music fits each area very well and does not overstay its welcome at all.- Arcade (roguelite) mode adds a ton of replayability. Beating it is hard enough, the side roguelite quests and high score chasing allows infinite replayability.Cons:- Non-hosts may experience lag, which ruins the multiplayer experience [case-by-case basis]- Would be nice for some skills to interact with each other more for multiplayer mayhem [Earth spike wall + Smash?]For a detailed full impressions video [8 minutes long], check out this video below!

Early Access Review
								First thing i would like to note, that at this current stage, the games storyline and area's are still being developed. And the development progress is in small and sometimes slow doses between updates. For me personally, i have stopped playing til the game is complete so my experiance is not lost by the partial development.With that in mind, do not let that put you off from purchasing the game. It will be one great experience once complete, and even between.Meanwhile, until the game is fully developed, you can optionally beta test and help the developers stamp out any nasty issue's found, make suggestions towards the development via the games forum found upon their site, or simply play the addictive Arcade mode. Or perhaps you just dont mind playing the game in partial installments."Grind"ea? True to it's name, there is some grinding involved here and there, though it is done and balanced rather well.I Love the detail that has been put into this "JRP Zelda type". From the artwork, to the gameplay details such as the skill system. Finding a game of this type with such TLC from the developers (also explains the slow rate of developement), that also supports cooperative multiplayer.. is just rare.One thing that the store descriptions fails to mention, is the existance of the crafting system (Unless that is a part of the "hidden content").Weapons, gear etc can be crafted from various ingredients found throughout the game.There is not much else i can tell you, apart from what the store page describes. So ill finish this with a personal rating..9/10 - Would buy it again.. and again. I Love this game, and i love it's ever promising future.

								Updated review It's good, I would say wait until it's FULL RELEASE to even consider buying- and before I start off this, let it be known I have nothing but love for this game and the devs themselves, they're great people, it's a great game but I need to be honest here.The multiplayer works perfectly, I honestly couldn't detect any syncing issues which was nice. I feel like the combat is a little too easy once you get the hang of it although I love the enemy variety in this game and every boss can provide a bit of challenge but outside of the bosses, the game is a breeze.The story is basically non-existent at this point but I will say the writing is charming and humorous, I actually caught myself laughing at some points. The updates are very infrequent and at this point and it's♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥me off, I won't hold anything back on that, since last year the story hasn't progressed in any meaningful way, I can't even bring myself to open this game anymore unless a friend asks me to play. Overall I give it a 3/10, I would give it a 10/10 if updates were more frequent but as a customer I'm very frustrated and frankly I'm tired of the early access game tropes.The arcade mode is also kind of fun, forgot about that, it's kind of like binding of isaac in a small small way, pretty difficult when playing solo.

number of helpful: 16 of 18 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Charming, fun, vibrant and addicting - this is one great RPG!In this world you are a Collector, someone who explores and adventures across the world in search of rare loot and items of power! Every enemy in the game has at least one rare "drop" to collect so this really is a game for players who love to collect/farm/grind! There is also a crafting system that can *GASP* actually make powerful and useful gear!The combat gives off vibes of Secret of Mana but its much less rigid and limited than the old school RPGs of yore are. You can choose freely amongst 1h melee with shield, 2h melee and 4 schools of magic (Fire, Earth, Ice and Air). You invest skill points into whatever skill you desire and then the combat becomes an awesome weave of offense and defense as you bust out your skills in real-time!Boss battles are great and plentiful as well! Really, this is a great action oriented RPG with a major emphasis on its addicting collection system (GRINDea, get it? :P) Usually "grinding" is looked poorly upon but honestly its quite addicting in this game and every enemy and boss can be beaten without taking a single point of damage so ultimately you don't actually have to grind - if you're really good!

content:
Posted: July 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								Secrets of Grindea is an ARPG inspired by old classics such as The Legend of Zelda, Secret of Mana etc.You play as a Collector (or a Collector to be) in the world of grindea, a world where everyone is obsessed with collecting items and despite the word "Grind" in the title, you never feel like you HAVE to grind, its always there as a side task to help you get some rare loot etc.It also features a very customisable skill system where you can effectively build a character you want, there are no unique classes as such and all the skills you see are the skills you will get, each skill has its benefits and drawbacks.The Game is split into 2 different modes, Story mode and Arcade mode, Story mode is exactly what you expect from most RPG's and Arcade mode is very Roguelike where each death is a learning experience (and trust me, you'll die A LOT)The Soundtrack is Amazing, i regret not purchasing it myself, it fits the game so perfectly.

number of helpful: 87 of 148 people (59%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								It's a good game, but I honestly feel that it's extremely overhyped for what it offers--which isn't much.  I wouldn't really play the game for its story, as it seems pretty basic and I didn't find there to be much character depth.  It does try and it does give you some background to the characters and features a nice "cinematic" of the player's mom (which is actually really awesome because they made it so that her hair+skin color is the same as whatever you chose for yourself).  But that's more of a game feature than something specifically story related--the story itself, like I said is pretty stereotypical.  Some people might like it, but after playing so many games, it just feels repetitive--if this was an mmo, you wouldn't even bother reading it.The combat has some nice elements (though I do remember being a bit frustrated with a few things--sorry, it's been over a year since I played this, so I can't remember the details very much) and the art is cute enough that I would like to continue playing it, but since the game is unfinished at the moment, my only options are to play Arcade Mode or to grind for cards.  I don't really want to grind for cards when their website's forum FAQ states there may be a potential wipe when the game is finished.  Maybe this has changed, but even so it feels odd to grind for something you may never use.The problem isn't that the game is unfinished--we knew that going into EA, but what we didn't know until after we had completed all there is to do was that it's been in development since 2011 and is still only about 30% to completion.  The description on Steam with the link to the devblog in bold paints the picture that development is constant and EA will soon be over, but this doesn't seem to hold true.  Many of the areas in the game that you try to go to will give you a little notification that it's not yet implemented.  (Also on this, if you try to go to another map and you're cooping, you will be denied access unless all party members are at standing on top of you--just a heads up for those who might be bothered by this.)  As is, I think there are about 10 or so hours of content in storymode.   On top of this, if you notice the Discussion Page on Steam features a locked sticky entitled, "Haven't played in over a year..." where in the last post, the developer states, "New threads will be locked, and if the same user keeps creating new ones we're going to assume they're just rabble rousing and we'll use the dusty ol' ban hammer that's mostly sitting in the corner."  Which boils down to: You are not allowed to mention the slow development.  Ever.  I don't know... I just don't think that kind of censorship is exactly right.Additionally, the website's FAQ states that they are not looking for additional people to help with the project and all positions are filled, so while they say things are slow because they only have three people to work on the game, they're not actively trying to remedy that, despite people offering to help.  I checked out the latest post on the devblog again, and one of the things that was written, "Definitely looking forward to another year of fun gamedev, and I hope you’ll all stay with us through our journey!" doesn't sound too hopeful that the game will be finished next year, either.  Again, though, I'm not trying to say the game itself is bad; it's just that... there's not much there.  I'm really sad to leave this with a negative review, but I just cannot comprehend how these issues seem to be so overwhelmingly glossed over.  We bought this game over a year ago and keep checking back only to feel really discouraged; fifteen dollars is a lot for someone to spend on something that doesn't seem to have a lot of hope at the moment and I just don't want anyone to be put in a situation where they end up disappointed.If the game is ever completed, I would probably change my recommendation, but at the moment, I don't think I can recommend it, sorry.

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Admittedly, I went into this game not knowing much about it at all, which is somewhat rare for me in this day and age. I did this because I felt I didn't need to know much about the game, my very first impression from the trailer and a youtube video sold me on the spot. And I can say, roughly 9 hours into the game as of this review, that my first impression was spot on. If you enjoy the classic action RPGs of the 1990's and early 2000's, such as Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past, Illusion of Gaia, or (obviously) Secret of Mana, then this game is for you and is well worth your time, money, and intrigue.From my perspective, this game offers 4 distinct areas of interest that define the experience:Story Mode Arcade ModeMultiplayerThe Progression System (Skills and Talents) I will be covering all 4, explaining my experiences and impressions of each.STORY MODEWhile a bit lacking in the engaging story aspect, Secret of Grindea's (SoG) Story Mode offers something many RPGs have failed to have for a while now: the elegance of simplicity. Many modern titles have an obsession with creating a novel's worth of narrative. Cutscene after cutscene, wall of text after wall of text, the experience of these titles are moreso about the story and presentation of it than the actual game.SoG takes the short and simple approach, where it gives enough story and narrative to provide context and motivation, but is spaced well enough where it does not feel like a chore to read through it all (having the option to skip cutscenes helps too). Not to say that the story isn't interesting, though. While simple and somewhat of a parady of other RPGs, many of the characters are likeable in their own right and their clever interactions are both entertaining and humurous. It's clear a lot of heart was put into the devolpment of this game from all of the silly and minor references to other games and characters.Putting aside the storytelling aspect of SoG, there's quite a bit of content packed into what is currently available (game is still in beta as of this review). From collectables, to crafting, to minigames, puzzles, Zelda-esque dungeons, side quests, arena challenges, and engaging and replayable boss fights, there's a lot to do. But my favorite aspects are the inclusion of a genuinely difficult hard mode that can be toggled on or off at any time and the ability to customize the look of your character in the form of hats and accessories (that override the look of your currently equipped armor).To review:Pros:Simple but effective narrativeInteresting and humurous dialoguePlethora of activities, side quests, and minigamesInteresting boss fightsHard ModeCons:Game not complete (with no ETA)ARCADE MODEArguably, this is where most of your time will go. This mode is SoG's roguelike feature, where you attempt to progress as far as you can through a serious of increasingly challenging rooms and obstacles on a single life. Much in the way of other roguelikes (such as Rogue Legacy), you have the ability the make succeeding runs easier in the form of unlocking perks. These are unlocked via a currency you obtain randomly as a drop and from completing quests and achievments.The farther you go and the better you do, the more points you will recieve. After each death, your points are tallied up and added to your total score across all games. After certain thresholds have been met, you will revieve rewards, such as cosmetics (hats and accessories), more NPCs to interact with, and more buildings/decorations for your hub. There is also a global leaderboard for the mode, so if you're into that sort of thing you can sate your fancy here.As for the actual content of the mode, it's challenging but rewarding. Like any other roguelikes, there are a lot of elements of randomness involved. The dungeon layout, challenges in each room, and the loot you get are all up to chance. However, this works as the combat system is based on skill moreso than raw stats. You will get farther in the dungeon because you got better rather than because you got some good luck on your drops. You find that you are excited to get as far as you can as that shows just how much better you got at the game more than anything else.Pros:Unlockable PerksAchievmentsLeaderboardReplayabilityCons:Can have a somewhat harsh learning curveCan feel repetative at timesLike story mode, not all of the floors are implemented yet.MULTIPLAYERWhile I have no personal experience with this feature myself, I have seen examples of this in videos and streams. From what I have seen, multiplayer is fairly smooth and simple to do. Multiplayer is available for both Story Mode and Arcade Mode, so if you have a group of friends you can enjoy all aspects of the game together with up to 4 people.Be that as it may, it's not perfect. Currently, there is no option to play with your friends locally. You will need to connect to each other through different computers, and each person will need to have a copy. Additionally, it lacks some quality of life functions such as being able to join someone from your friends list. And, as one would expect from online play, there can exist some connection issues and bugs (although I've yet to see any).Pros:Can play with up to 4 peopleCan play in both Story Mode and Arcade ModeSmooth and stable online playCons:Can have some connection issues and bugsLacks QoL polishNo Local PlaySKILLS AND TALENTSAn RPG needs to have some form of progression, and SoG does it with it's ability system. What makes this one stand out from the rest is its simplicity and its lack of restrictions. There are no skill trees, no level/stat requirements, you just choose the skills you like and roll with it. And so much is added to this game because of it.There are a varity of skills that appeal to all forms of play, be it aggressive, defensive, evasive, melee, range, single target, AoE, Burst, DoT, etc. And given the lack of restrictions on obtaining skills, you can create a massive amount of different and interesting builds. Want to be an aggressive and fast melee striker? Go for it. Want to be a long-ranged magic nuker? Sure! Want to combine both melee and magic for a hybrid spellsword? That's cool too.Additionally, a lot of the skills from different branches work well together. For instance, Static shock is a spell that will do additionally damage very time you hit with a physcial attack. You can restore charges for this skill from using physical skills or doing perfect guards, meaning this skill can be used in all kinds of builds, both offensive and defensive.While I would argue a need for more skills, the simplicity of the current design is also appealing and useful. While some talents prove to be more useful than others, many of the skills have their uses and can work well given the right circumsances.In the end, what gives this game a lot of replayability, both in Story Mode and in Arcade Mode, is the progression system and the appeal of trying out new builds and tactics.Pros:Non-restrictiveSkills work well togetherInteresting and thoughtful effectsEasy to make and try new builds and tacticsSimple and easy to understandCons:Some talents not as useful as othersArguably not enough skills to facilitate variety

content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Many reviews note that this game is a ripoff and has slow development. And frankly, yeah, it's been in development forever. There is a dev blog and it is updated fairly often but there is still a lack of justification for the length of time it's taken to complete the game.That aside, this is not like other early access games. This is a really, really well-made game with a lot of content already in it. There is clearly a lot of love that went into this game down to the sprite animations, the little cutscenes, puzzles, and gameplay itself. I went through the main portion of the content in 15 hours and beyond that there's achievements and arcade mode which is insidious and takes forever. Co-op is really fun and unique especially considering most games don't offer it, ever.This was without a doubt worth the $15 even unfinished. I loved playing this game and I was instantly addicted. It's extremely refreshing to see quality of this magnitude with indie development. And yet, what's disappointing is the lack of additions in such a length of time. This game has a colossal amount of potential to be even more than it is right now. If you're okay with 50% of a game and 10-15 hours of gameplay, you won't regret purchasing it.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								Secrets of Grindea is an awesome little game with a great art style and a lot of care put into it. Has a well written story which is playable entirely in co op (a HUGE plus, more games need to do this) and old school, SNES style action rpg gameplay. The writing is funny, the world is enjoyable to explore and beautifully crafted, the gameplay is simple but really fun and challenging at times. If you're looking for a  cool co op game, this is it. If you're looking for a cool game in general, this is also it. One slight downside: I recommend playing this with a controller, since keyboard controls are a bit iffy. Support games like these!

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
Early Access Review
								For some odd reason, the game reminds me a lot of Paper Mario for the N64. I'm not exactly sure why... there's hardly any similarities.I tried the demo of this game (lead up to the arena fight), and it had me sold. I was hesitant to buy it at the time, on sale, or was released... the formar took over (and I'm glad, worth every $ and then some). This game just... pulls me in and refuses to let go. I have to pry myself away from the game! (or till I feel my bladder being full to the brim...)I picked hard difficulty as normal felt... easy for me... I have completely underestimated hard difficulty than I usually do for RPG games! At first I thought the game was just a collection of popular and maybe hardly used RPG tropes... well I'm not completely wrong. The story in the game is... interesting to say the least (up to what I reached)... at least I think there's a story? Somewhere? Maybe I overlooked it half way...The game does encourage AND reward you for grinding/farming. I've noticed several times the spawn rate increases if it registers you grinding/farming, unlike other RPGs the spawn rate will decrease and/or would spawn mobs elsewhere instead of the spot you're on. (Looking at you MMORPG's... especially the F2P ones...) For some reason... grinding/farming isn't so trivial or boring than other games. Probably because I'm not seeing high leveled players showing me up one-hitting everything while I'm struggling (Always saw that as bad form) or the struggle isn't worth it.Some of the mobs I feel move a bit too fast for hard mode. Strong, more HP, and additional moves I understand but... some just don't pause at all. Rather have the mobs pause less than in Normal than not pausing at all. Be nice if mobs had a weakness and resistance. Having a hard time just trying to kill them with no disadvantages.The boss fights... either the bosses need a little tweaking, the leveling system needs bit of a fix, and/or the skills need to be reworked. There's been a few boss fights that nearly made me just go to normal difficulty (I had to temporary for the sentry mini-boss due to the stupid orbs!) Either too much is going on for me to register what's happening, I'm unable to get strong enough to properly face this boss/foe, and/or the skills I have are weak than they should be.I've nearly crafted every item on the current list... on bit of a card hunt now. See cards as a reward for grinding/farming excessively as they give you benefits whether to your stats or purchases (that I've seen so far). Wish leveling actually increased your stats than just give you points to spend... I shouldn't feel so weak than I should be for (current) end-game bosses (toward Winter, Hydras, Toy Machine, etc.). Granted it's hard, but shouldn't be dark-souls difficult! (That's what it felt like most of the time after the numerous times of being frustrated at bosses to the point of nearly tossing my laptop out the one story window!!!)Pick this up at its price of $15. Shouldn't wait for a sale, unless you're low on cash, to enjoy this. If you rather play a finished product than in development, then you'll be waiting for quite some time. Half of the story content is in the stable beta right now.I'll most likely either update or completely rewrite this review when the game is finished. I think I'll wait till this game is finished before I continue any further in the story though.Update: Tried a bit of Arcade Mode... it's not very forgiving that it discourages me. Reminds me of Rogue Legacy but harsher...-----Check out more games I see that deserve more attention from my curator group:BluePaw's Underrated Games ListJoin and/or follow if you wish.

content:
Posted: March 18
Early Access Review
								Do not buy this game right now, but definitely put it on your wishlist and buy it immediately when it's finished.Assuming you're looking at this now because it's been recommended by Steam, or you're searching for the kind of game that is reminiscent of Secrets of Mana/Chrono Trigger/Any of those classic SNES RPGs, you're going to absolutely want this game, but don't spoil the experience by getting it now.  It's so good.  They've gotten the feeling of an old school RPG down perfectly, but married it with modern playability and UI.  I've played it with my two best friends in coop and it brought us back over a decade to nights we'd spend sitting around a TV enjoying old consoles together.Secrets of Grindea's store page is the one that I visit most frequently, watching the updates hoping for content completion, because its gameplay is perfection, but when I played it was 25% content complete, and I was pretty disillusioned when we hit that wall.  I want the full experience, and I'm chomping at the bit.I know development takes a long time, especially with a small team, and they're doing a phenomenal job, but if I could, I'd go back and stop myself from playing until the full game was released.  If you're like me and you CAN'T wait, then ignore my warning and buy it, because this is going to be an absolute treat, but know that you're going to be like me, constantly checking the store page for more news.

Early Access Review
								I bought this game so that my girlfriend and I would have a game to play LAN co-op together.  It was a completely blind purchase and I am so happy I did it.  The game has so much to see even in it's early access state.  With a fun combat system, great story content, well thought out dungeons, loot driven crafting and a ton of replayablility via arcade mode, this game actually shocked me with how much they packed in.
