It successfully walks a fine line of being a great RPG and being a self aware parody or classic RPGs.

number of helpful: 10 of 12 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
Early Access Review
								For a Early Access game this is highly impressive. For one the amount of effort and polish here is staggering. Spritework is very detailed and charming and the animations are top notch all around. NPCs don't just sit around, they walk, talk, sneeze, cough, sigh, eat some chicken, work and more. They are all doing something and each one feels unique and goes a long way to draw you into the game world.The gameplay is very tight and responsive. You have a robust amount of options when it comes to combat style thanks to weapon skills and various schools of magic. Specialize or mix and match, its all up to you and the game encourages it. The option to buy back level up points is a nice feature if not pricey. The game also has tons of great design choices. Puzzle challenges let you rewind various steps of the puzzle. Pushed a block in the wrong space? No problem, step on a tile to undo it without having to reset the whole thing. And that feature is nice cause these puzzles can rack your brain on occasion. When it comes to crafting you can pin recipes your working on to your hud so you can know what you need at all times. Tons of smart game design on display here.And not to mention the games Arcade mode which honestly could have been a whole game by itself. Its a permadeath roguelike style experience which asks you to go into randomly generated dungeons to rack up as many points as possible in one run by not only clearing rooms but being smart and quick about it. These points go towards improving your hub town. You can also find special rare items you can cash in for permanent perks that carry over from character to character. Also this whole game has 4 PLAYER ONLINE CO-OP! For Story AND Arcade mode with various features that go with that too like competitive minigames.My mind is blown that this is a Early Access game cause good lord its already far acceded its asking price for me. Get a copy or two for your buddies and enjoy some good old fashioned action RPG goodness. ^^

content:
Posted: January 15
Early Access Review
								I've been playing the beta non stop for around 2 days now, and I've got to say that I am very impressed. It has all the charm of older RPG's like 'Legend of Zelda- The Minish Cap' but with a multitude its own little flourishes. The story line (so far) has kept me interested, and the side quests aren't just dull fodder. It took me a a short while to get used to navigating the large menu, and I wish I could banish my pet to the farm (not the metaphor) instead of just "hiding" it. Sometimes the graphics makes it hard to distinguish what is background art and what is moveable or collectable items, especially when first starting, but it doesn't take long to become used to it.Altogether I think it's a fantastic game, although I am very biased towards that particular RPG style its a real throw-back to old school gameboy games. I will definitely be getting the fully completed version and I'm glad that the developers are taking their time to make the most out of this game. I hope that the game run time isn't too short in its entirety but from how long the developers are taking, I'm sure these fears are unfounded.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								When I first saw this game I thought it was some JRPG a game focused on story with little gameplay but it would make up for that with how extensive the customization is. I figured 17.00$ for a unfinished game might not be worth it even if it is good because it is still in early access and would have so little to the game that it is not worth it. The game looked like a higher quality indie maker game and that was not what I was interested in so I dismissed it. I wanted something that will have lots to do good gameplay and lots of replay value. I was really wrong about the game. It is so good it is a contender to be one of my favorite games of all time. The game has great replay value, online multilayer, great combat, the fishing mini game is actually okay and it has a interesting but overall funny story that is skipable.  This game have great replay value there are many different monsters that can drop up to 4 different items when you defeat them, some are crafting items sometimes you can get some armor, a sword or a shield. Sometimes you need to gather crafting items to craft a new item or you can just find a new hat, sword if you kill enough monster that drop items. You can play the game with 4 players making the game harder the more people that play but the game is still fun to play because you can spend time focusing on collecting all the items in the game. I have almost played the game over 24 hours and I still have not gathered all the items, cards, achievement and even finished the story. You can change the game from easy to hard in the middle of the game making it very fair. The game has replay value because you could replay the game to have a magic user build otr a melee user build or something like that. The gameplay is fun there is normal and hard difficulty hard adds a few more monsters to the levels makes them more aggressive, faster and stronger. The magic in the game is fair and not overpowered like it is in other games. You have powerful magic but summoning a monster reduces your energy while your summoned monster or passive spells is out. When you level up your base stats go up and if you want extra challenge you could play the game without leveling up and for a price you can respend your points on new spells and abilities. The game does something crazy it makes it fun and gives you a reason to kill over 1000 slimes. You would want to kill the slimes for exp, money, collectibles, cards, crafting items, and even if you already have these you can sell them for money and give them to other players. And the best part is killing slimes is fun they get smarter the more you kill and if your not careful even easy monsters can hurt you.    The story is great it is funny, full of references to games like legend of Zelda other games anime movies etc. The story is interesting enough to watch a few times but thankfully you can skip it if this is your 20th time playing the game. The game has fair DLC there is a 5 dollar hat DLC that is honest that if you play 5 dollars you will give the devs more money so if you want to support them you can. There is no cheap DLC that gives players an edge like golden armor swords or unfair things like that. The games multiplayer is great and there is little lag for me and you can play arcade, the story, VS with other players and its not like the game needed that because the game is fun just playing by yourself. So do I recommend this game YES it has great challenge, it has some of the best replay value I have seen in a story, the gameplay is great  the collectibles are fun and worth getting, the multiplayer have 3 fun modes VS, story and arcade ( you can also play mini games in the story with others) and they are still making the game? It is worth it for sure and when they keep this system add more content, collectibles and things like that this game would be my new favorite game of all time. I really thing you should consider buying this game for a fun game to play buy your self and a fun game to play with friends. the only posible thing that the game could add to make it better would be local multiplayer. the game has good gameplay like castle crashers, replay value and collectables somewhat like MMO games and a short but sweet story.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 31, 2016
Early Access Review
								Secrets of Grindea.....how do I say this in a way that people will think, "Wow, this games sounds good, I should play this?" Well I don't know honestly. But I'll try my best!Okay so here we go! Secrets of Grindea, first look before buying it I though to myself, "Eh, this games doesn't look too bad. I hope it's not like every other rpg I've played." So I bought this game knowing that it was still early access. What a gamble! Okay now lets talk about my first reaction.I booted up the game, (do people even say that anymore?) and was welcomed by a nice and catchy theme song, one I still cannot get out of my head. I proceeded to select stroymode, singlplayer and boom I was in the game! I played through the intro, the first boss, the second boss, and the first two areas. I fell in love with the game because it was really unique and interesting, let's not forget about fun!Fighting! The combat is smooth and not boring, plus the cartoonish style makes it enjoyable. Two handed swords are slow, one handed swords are fast like they should be and wands make magic dealy but don't hurt much. The skills they have add a sort of customization to the game that can make a player speicalize in what they want wether its a tank role,  supportrole, or somwhere in between. Magic in the game is fun though some of the schools of magic,which are ground, wind, ice, and fire, are better than the other this can lead to a broken system where one school of magic in the game is never used making it pointless. Another great feature of the game is the pets! You got to love the pets they're soo CUTE!!! *cough* *cough* On a professional note pets are a fun feature that really adds to the game. The best part of the pets is  that you can feed them certain items that boost your overall stats. This is great like I said previously but broken becuase the game itself has no protection against hacking. You could hack in a billion speed potions if you wanted to and feed them to your pet which makes you OP as heck and can ruin the gaming experience.Lets talk about the gameplay, so far in the game at the date this is written you can only play the game up to Mt.Bloom, which is okay because the game is still in EARLY ACCESS. The monsters can be challenging at times and make you upset. I don't know how many I died by a monster and said," I am going to destroy your face!" I am looking at you Halloweed. The leveling system is pretty fair with a great exp rate through out the story. The bosses are nice with a unique challenge for all of them, you have to create tactics and learn the bosses attack patterns before you can triumph over them. WARNING: Prepare to get creamed by some bosses!! The level spikes in each area you go to are mostly appropriate besides the third area which can get a tad tough becuase of certain enemies. ( I swear the Yeti species hate me >.> )What is an RPG without multiplayer, am I right? Secrets of Grindea goes about there Co-op experience just fine. You can play story mode with friends or play Arcade mode with friends. There is no match making feature currently in the game so you have to go make some friends to play multiplayer. During the story mode when you play multi player whoever is the host of the game it's their story, so don't expect to pick up where you left off in the story mode with your friends if you try to play solo. When you play solo it is your own story on the specific character. The Arcade mode is where you traverse through floors trying to make it to the end, if you die you start all over and loose your gear. There is a warning though, this mode could potentially ruin the story line.Overall this game is really fun and I reccommend that eveyone gives it a try. I rate this game, IN ITS CURRENT STATE AS OF 6/26/2016,  8.5/10 Paws

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
Early Access Review
								Secrets of Grindea so far is a great game. Plenty of challenges both in  Story and Arcade Mode. Skills and character movement are responsive, and there are subtle cancellations that make the combat somewhat customizable. The skill choices aren't limited in any way other than being less effective if you use certain weapons. The skills require a "charge" and unlock more powerful versions once you've leveled up the skills enough.Story-wise it has some solid moments. A cinematic-driven story with a lot of humor/comic relief. There are some potential plot twists starting to evolve and that may give the story a bit of a turn and spice things up a bit. Overall while i'm not a fan of story/cinema in games, it was enjoyable and not too dramatic or overdone like what a lot of titles do.Creativity-wise, there is a recipe-driven crafting system. You essentially grind some items and are able to put the items together and figure out what the "unknown item" is. The character's house is being implemented and there is potential that players will be able to add particular items to that house, and perhaps in a certain order. Other than that players also have some room on choosing their combat style. A player may be a meteor summoning "shieldmaiden" that uses a magical spear instead of the typical sword/staff.Other than that there's still a lot of the game being developed. This review was for a particular steam badge. ;) I'd have written a review upon official release instead of during early access, and likely will udpate this review once SoG is complete.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								Fun game for what there is at the moment. Though there isn't much content in the story mode which i find strange because this game has been in development for years now and they have only managed to finish two temples and a few zones (then they have the cheek of asking for money to go towards coffee breaks in the form of day one DLC) it's still a great bit of fun and the arcade mode adds a lot of replayability. I can't say i'm a fan of the fact they have placed in a online leaderboards as to me that encourages cheating and there's no way you're going to get the #1 spot unless you too cheat and then it makes it seem pointless to do if you're wanting to take part in the arcade mode for the competitive purpose of beating other players. Though this is and the current lack of content in the story mode (at the time of this build i'm sure this will change in later versions) are my only complaints about the game.The music and sound effects are spot on and you can tell they have heavy inspiration from older RPG games and has a great nostalgic feel about it. I played through the game co-op with one friend and i have to say the net code is spot on and we had no problems with lag what so ever and the game seemed input perfect along with not being too restricted to where you can go in co-op. You and your allies still all have to commit to going to a new zone before the game takes you all there but you're not bound together when you're in that zone. The gameplay is flawless in design too and you feel like you have all the control over your character and when you ♥♥♥♥ up and die it is YOUR fault and not the game's. The game has the perfect balance of fun and challenge and the spells/abilities all seem to have their uses though some seem a lot weaker early game and some also seem a lot weaker later game so it's worth experimenting with the abilities as some may be more usefull early game but end up being weak towards the end.Highly recommend checking this gem out as it lives up to the hype and i am extremely exited in seeing what they add in future updates.

Early Access Review
								Me and my friends absolutely love this game! I have a group of friends and we are always looking on here for new games that we can all play together and we have dedicated many hours into this game. At the moment we have beat the game and are patiently waiting for the next update. Pros:Great GraphicsGreat ReplayabilityChallengingAddictinggreat game to play alone or with friendsYou can beef up your character's skills as much as you want. there is litterally no limit to how powerful you can be.Cons:Gets laggy if there are too many enemies on the screen at once (they keep respawning if you keep killing them which is good if you want items or xp but bad if it causes lag.)You have to have a seperate save for playing alone than with friends. Whoever hosts the game when you play with the same friends has to continue to be the host every time because the story mode continues from the hosts story. If you wanted to play on your own it will start a new game for you but you will be able to keep your skills and items from the other game with your friends. Alse if somebody else decides to host the game it will also start a new game. This was a bit of an issue because we could not play the game and continue on story mode unless the host was wanting to play as well. We could only play on his terms. taking forever for them to come out with an update.But aside from the cons it is a very fun game and I would recommend it to anybody. By far my favorite game.

								The game shows promise. It's a love letter to games like Zelda: A Link to the Past. The animation of the sprites is awesome, and the environments are varied. The dungeons are absolutely fantastic and are definitely the highlight of the game. But it's been incomplete for an absurdly long time at this point. I understand that they want to ensure that it is polished and as good as they can make it for when it gets a full release, but there is really no excuse at this point for why this game is taking so long to make. I can't recommend a game that may only get released a year from now. What we have now is solid and polished, but short and leaves you hanging. I'm worried that when this DOES finally get released (if it ever does), that the hype train will have already left.

								What can I say... it is an unfinished game that I just keep playing. Over 100 hours in fact. It is ridiculously charming and tons of fun.Some things to keep in mind though...You know that "grind" in the title? If you want to complete everything there is definitely grinding. content:
Posted: August 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Secrets of Grindea is incredibly fun! I absolutely love co-op RPGs, and this ARPG has potential. It has a Secret of Mana/A Link to the Past vibe, and after trying out the free demo, I immediately bought it. While the game is still in early access, there is plenty to do. Once you run though the story (as far as you can, it's still in development), there are likely still items to craft, a pet to level to increase your stats, and an arcade mode that is challenging and addictive. As of right now, the game has controller support for a wired 360 controller, and you can use software to bind buttons of other controllers to specific keys, so you can make different controllers work (I'm using the PS4 controller) - the game feels great with a controller, so it's definitely worth doing if the keyboard set-up just isn't working for you.I strongly recommend at least trying the free demo - as there's nothing to lose. It's a relatively small download, and while  you could probably rush through pretty quickly, if you take your time to explore and take things in a little, you'll get a decent amount of content for a demo. The demo can also be played cooperatively, so it's probably worth trying to get a friend or two (or three, if you can) to try it with you!

content:

Early Access Review
								Secrets of Grindea is an exersize in nostalgia for me. The game feels and plays much like Secret of Mana and Secrets of Evermore, both games which influenced my childhood and love for RPG's. Secrets of Grindea is one of my favourite games on steam, period.My wife and I have spend many hours playing this game together, fighting bosses, grinding equipment, enjoying the soundtrack and even discussing gameplay and where we hope the game will go from here, many hours after we've finished a session. We both hope the game does wonderfully, and that the team who makes it keeps up their hard work!It's good to see such talent in the game industry, and I hope the creators are very proud of themselves for the piece of art they've built. I know I certainly am proud of them.That being said, the game is very much early access, and the campaign isn't quite finished yet. It looks like there's a long way to go yet, and I eagerly devour each and every update as it's put out.If you liked Secret of Mana, and enjoy a good old fashioned item gathering rpg, pick this game up now. Better yet, get 2 copies and play with a friend- It's definitely worth it.

number of helpful: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								(Note: Review made after playing through around 50% completion of the beta with 2 other friends.)Secrets of Grindea is an action rpg that takes cues from top down Legend of Zelda games and Secret of Mana games.You run around, fight monsters, and use hotkeyed spells while wearing cool hats.The music is well, nothing that stands out to me though. (Yet!)It features a very large amount of items to collect, craft, and fight with (even in the beta, I feel) and quite a few spells, passives, and skills to play with.The game's story revolves around you and up to 3 other friends adventuring around the world, gathering gear and fighting monsters so you can become the best hoarder in the whole world.I can break down the gameplay into 4 types; Boss fighting, Enemy Fighting, Crafting and Exploring/Puzzles.Now, I wouldn't say the bosses are bad, hell, some even verge into the point of having so many projectiles on the screen you could swear you are playing a bullet hell, and are still well made, but i'd say that the bosses have way too much hp. Examples of this are the "Raging Toy Machine" Boss (I think that is what it is called?) which has too much hp and spams too many projectiles at once to even revive your friends, such as lines of dropping bombs, random dropping bombs, spawning monsters that also spawn bombs, normal monsters that charge at you, and a floor hazard that sends a toy train at you at random angles (Since the tracks on the floor constantly change direction) all at the same time. Also, another boss guilty of this would be a certain cube boss that deals insane amounts of damage but is somewhat easy to dodge, yet has crazy amounts of health. Some normal enemies have this problem too, such as the Yeti monsters. I suggest that the Toy Machine Boss has either less hp, or spams less things. Perhaps remove the bombs it drops?Enemy fighting is pretty fun, some monsters dodge, some use projectiles, some shield other monsters, it has a nice amount of spice without overdoing it. However, I do not like the damage sponge nature of the Sky Dungeon's Birds, and the Snow area's Yetis.I feel that the crafting can be improved in the way that some drops are extremely rare, instead of having the drops be really rare, make it so the drops are semi-rare or drop from the monsters in specific areas/quests, but have to pay certain amounts of money to actually craft the gear. The better the gear, the more money you would pay. It would solve the problem in that more often then not, shops have either way better gear then what you currently have, or junk gear that you can't improve or craft with, or, as another suggestion, make it so the gear shops sell basic gear that can be improved into better items. (Some gear from stores already does this, but it would be better if more gear could be upgraded.)Exploring areas is usually rewarded well, along with treasure maps that give you either image hints or riddles to where the treasure is buried, and some puzzles that involve pushing blocks around into a certain area to open a door. (More fun then it sounds.)Another thing to mention is the pixel art style of this game is extremely pleasing to the eye, and the animation is very fluid and appealing to watch. It's also worth noting most npc's do things such as farming and shoveling snow, which adds a bit of life to the game. The monsters are also, very well animated.Something that I do not like, is that in online gameplay, only the host will have the quests completed on their side. Therefore, playing the game by yourself after doing some quests with a friend, means you will have to go through those quests again in singleplayer if you wish to do so. I suggest to the devs that they make it so if the group finishes a quest, all players main story should be updated to reflect that, so they do not have to go through the quests again. Also, it's worth noting you cannot get quest rewards more then once, meaning, if you do it online with a friend, go to single player, and do the quest again, you cannot get the item from finishing that quest again.Overall, I recommend this game even in it's beta state, I have not run into any bugs or problems quite yet, and I feel the game will be even better once more content, polish, and balancing is added to the game.

Learning the move set for each new enemy is exciting as it adds a certain difficulty to the game.The music isn¨t obnoxious and is atually quite good. Well thought out scene/music selection. You can play the bosses over and over again to collect their cards and items. You can bait animals and train them to fight or bring them back to your house. There¨s plenty of side quests and mini-games to help you along the way. If you¨re ever played Secrets of Mana or the Aveyond series you might want to give this a try. The currrent build has a lot to offer so far. About 75% of the upgrades are unlockable and plenty of story to wet your appetite.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								In terms of other games: imagine Secret of Mana, with a structure that lets you just hop in and play with your friends, in a lighthearted Ragnarok Online setting.Secrets of Grindea is a smooth, charming 2D hack and slash with cute enemies and a fun world to explore that doesn't take itself too seriously. Fighting mobs of enemies feels great, and there are some cool bosses. Quests and areas are easy to understand without being too straightforward. The structure is pretty linear but offers some fun diversions in the form of collectible items, crafting recipes, and short side quests. Cooperative play is well-implemented in terms of interface and networking code, but doesn't really require you to specialize your characters to fight as a team. Overall, it's fun! It's like snack food (something familiar to satisfy a craving) but it's well-made, crisp, cheesy snack food.

content:
Posted: August 9, 2015
Early Access Review
Even though this is in Early Access, it is quite polished. Not a bug in sight, and there is plenty of game to sink your teeth into here. I was leary of the price, but its definately worth it. This is a throw-back to some great games of fairly long ago. I definately feel some heavy SNES Zelda and Secret of Mana vibes here. Like those, it also has some fairly heavy MetroidVania elements where you will be backtracking through the open world to access areas you previously couldn't. Pros:+Great artwork.+Great feel to it - it plays really well. Controller support and rebindability is great in this title.+Music is fitting to this style, and is not generic - it is its own thing.+Awesome level of RPG character customizability.+Loads of quests even now. I love the treasure maps. Lots of sidequests, and they are all well done.+Even though the light 'grinding' humor is there - the game never really feels that grindy (ironically enough lol).+I love when the characters clothes/hair/etc. is customizable and changes with changing items.+Storyline is well written - I am not skipping through it yet ;)Cons:-Online multi is awesome but I really wish they would add local so I don't have to purchase a second copy for my wife to play.-Hurry up and finish the unfinished zones already :D !!!If this sounds like something you would like - I guarantee you will not be disapointed with this even in Early Access.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								Easily the highest quality and most worthwhile "early access" game I've purchased in a long time. This game is a breath of fresh air. It borrows a lot of inspiration from the handheld Legend of Zelda games, and who doesn't love Zelda? It is simple to play and easy to learn, yet it has a lot of depth involved in it so that it doesn't feel shallow. There are no bugs, no crashes.. multiplayer worked seemlessly from the first time I tried and every time since. If you plug and unplug a controller in while the game is running, it changes over flawlessly with no hiccups. The music is fantastic and the graphics are fun and colorful! Besides the few things missing from the game that the developers plan to add before it's out of early access, you can hardly tell that it's not a finished game. Well worth the price as it stands now, even if the game isn't completely finished. I'm looking forward to getting the full experience once the game is finally finished.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
Early Access Review
								8/10A solid game, considering as of August 2016 it's in Early Access. What do you get for 10.99? You get a modern retro looking rpg clearly inspired by the SNES era, with the option to play solo or with up to 3 friends with either keyboard or controller (I recommend you use controller). The gameplay is captivating: the boss battles especially are well crafted and not to mention very challenging. These battles do a good job of incorporating the co-op aspect although the battles are almost as fun solo, albeit slightly easier.The world has a variety of locations and each is unique both in visuals and inhabitants. The music and sound effects are excellent. The story is funny in parts but not the main attraction. Where the game really shines is with its weapon and class systems. There are lots of attacks to use whilst in combat using a range of melee weapons, magic and specials. The game constantly allows you to level up skills and gain new ones. Like in most games from this genre, you have the choice on which skills you'd like to focus on more, for example making your character's health high so you can act more as a tank, rushing into swarms of enemies whilst a friend attacks from afar with magic or a bow. Improving your attacks is rewarding and, in my opinion, is one of the most enjoyable aspects about Secrets of Grindea. Quests involve puzzles, exploration and quite a bit of reading (obviously, although cutscenes can be skipped). Overall it is a great game that is easily woth its price. The only negatives would be: it has a mediocre story and missed the oportunity to make pets aid your character in battle (instead they just follow you around and that's it).

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2016
Early Access Review
								I played the demo through, sat on it for a day, and decided I absolutely should buy the game.  It seems inspired by games like Link to the Past (one of my favourites) and has a similar feel to it.  I like that there is a lot of depth to characters, though if you go for a plain 1h or 2h fighter you'll probably end up with a sort of samey character as you level up all of the 1h or 2h skills.  That said, there are tons of options for combinations with various kinds of magic and skills, though I would like if leveling up skills had more of an effect than 1-2% at a time for most of them, to further increase character diversity.The depth is very good in that there is a lot to do with your character, but not in a confusing way.  I was surprised when I found out you can also level up pet skills to further increase stats, and collecting monster cards also gives solid bonuses.  Looking back, it doesn't seem very complicated now that I've played through the current game a couple times, because it's easy to understand.  If you want to play through the game just mashing the attack button, that's fine (it will be really hard though), but you also have the option to level your skills in such a way that you can set up crazy combos and blow everything up.  The combat later on gets exciting enough that it's fun even to grind mobs looking for the card drop, both against the easy mobs and hard ones.If you like the demo, and are willing to pay for a promising early access game, I recommend it.  The game feels very polished, it's just a tad short at the moment (~8-10h to get through the story mode)

Early Access Review
								I rarely get this excited about a game, but i absolutely fell in love with this game instantly when i started playing it. I think it's a regular slime and the peckos doll for thier animation.Suggestions:*Infinite scaling dungeon!! (star ocean style!)*monster catching and breeding for the arena! (ff10 style!)*add in the multi-player games asap, even before more single player content to increase replay value. (think Mario party!)*PVP arena of some kind. Maybe ranked matches with special items people compete for.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL;DR: Buy this game. Many references, fun story and gameplay but tough as nails bosses.[Some minor spoilers ahead, be warned]What is good about this game:- Being able to select the visual appearence of one item while keeping the stats of another if you choose. No longer must you choose between style and function. You want a chicken hat with the protection of an iron helmet? you got it.- So many references. In my 7 hours I have notices 3 Pokemon references, a Mario reference, multiple Legend of Zelda references, 2 South Park references, a LITERAL Gundam boss, a well-known youtuber cameo in character and probably multiple more that I have missed.- Funny dialogue and interesting characters.- Impressive variety of skills to learn and base your playstyle on. (Several elements with 3 spells each plus many one and two handed weapon skills)What is bad/can be improved:- Menus are a bit annoying. For example if I want to make something and I lack the items needed, I can see if I have enough of item A, if I need more of item B or if I havent discovered Item C, BUT It will not tell me how much MORE of item B I need, which is a bit annoying. The difference between Silver points, Gold points and Talent orbs could also be explained better. I got a fair way into the game before realising what Talent orbs were and that I could spend them.- Some of the bosses feel a bit like Bullet Hells, and it can be VERY frustrating having to redo bosses over and over again since you keep dying to an onslaught of attacks on the screen. Maybe this is intended and I'm just not used to the difficulty, but I think if it is impossible to beat a boss with 1hp, you are doing something wrong as the boss is becoming less Skill based and more Luck based (such as the Winter boss, where he teleports several times and creates multiple ice pillars while launching fists of snow. He can effectively box you in to a point where you end up being hurt by his fist because you cannot move, or by the spikes as you try to avoid said fist. Or the Present machine where you have 6 presents, multiple bombs falling from the ceiling and several trains moving past).- Block mechanics can be improved slightly. I find myself taking damage if I drop my shield after an attack, even if the enemy has moved back or the projectile has vanished.I have high hopes for this game and hopefully this game is finished into the masterpiece it has the potential to be, and isn't another forgotten Early Access game.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
Early Access Review
 Early Access Done Right There's just those few times where an early access game comes out, and it's brilliant. This is one of them. I first saw Secrets of Grindea debut on Desura, way back when. I've had my eye on the game for years as I've been skeptical of unfinished indie titles. Now a friend and I own Secrets of Grindea and it's fantastic. It's everything a good RPG needs and it's not even finished yet. Here are some points. PROS Fantastic, and I mean absolutely extraordinary pixel graphics. Some areas completely blew my mind because of how wonderful the scenery looked.Expertly crafted levels give a smooth feel to the game. The plains in the beginning felt chaotic. Felt like it had a sense of wildlife. The town had a clever building layout, the flying fortress felt symmetric and not too maze like. The Halloween map had a wonderful border effect, winding and narrow paths and perfect but not too difficult maze-like structure.Upbeat and catchy soundtrack deserving of it's own DLC.Excellent, sometimes halarious sidequests keep the player engaged every time a main story plot was advanced through.Mindboggling puzzles and secrets that make you think in order to get the reward rather than have you kill a generic miniboss (While minibosses are a thing in the game, they are rare and require some skills to take out.)Up to 4 player supported co-op that really shines. The main story has subtle changes to accomodate to a party with the host being considered the 'main character' while the others were his equally as powerful and important friends.Competetive or Uncompetitive loot share allows for a race-to-the-loot type of co-op gameplay or a relaxed type of co-op gameplay where everyone gets the same items from chests but generic enemy loot drops are split randomly throughout the group so that everyone get's a slice of the bloodied pie.Extensive skill system and trees allowed for all types of gameplay with no class restrictions. Be a Claymore weilding mage, or a Duelist that uses both a Sword and Shield and Two-Handed. Become a jack-of-all-trades with the 4 magic types (Fire, Air, Water, Earth) and a master of none.Ingenious inventory system allows for both and equipment and vanity slots and also allows you the ability to 'transmog' your equipment such as wands, swords, and shields to look like previously collected weapons without the sacrifice in stats. Same goes for armor.You can have a smiling cloud that craps lightning on your foes. CONS With up to 4 player co-op, the screen can end up having a lot going on in one small space. This is especially true in some small boss arenas like the GUN-DAM fight where you have to really pay attention to where you're going. While also making sure you and your friends stay out of harms way.In some areas like the Halloween Forest, a lot of enemies can be in the same areas at once. This can make solo-play challenging especially as enemies respawn on a seemingly short respawn timer that can make battles turn hairy at a moments notice.The mix of magic, skills, basic attacks, and enviornmental awareness can sometimes really disorient people. It's difficult to fight multiple small enemies at once while also keeping an eye on your remaining energy, switching between normal and special attacks, blocking with your shield, AND keeping an eye on your shield-block meter. This sort of combat inspires a rushed and adrenaline-fueld high octane battle enviornment giving people a rush to smash their keys as quickly as possible. At least that's what happens with me. And this usually ends up with me not noticing my health dropping or my friend ending up dead right next to me.The crafting system is intuitive and mysterious, with some recipies not being able to be unlocked until you find a certain item from a dropped creature. For example, the icon for Honey was greyed out until I managed to kill a bee and get myself one unit of Honey. Along with this, the item your crafting tells you the stats OF the item BEFORE you make it, just so you don't accidentally make something you can't use. Why is this a flaw? Well this isn't a flaw in itself, the flaw comes from the process of MAKING the item. For example, to make an Apple Hat I had to take a Straw Hat and gather 60, count 'em, SIXTY APPLES. This can make the game feel grindy, no pun intended. I'm not exactly sure if that's an intended feature or not, but it's not a huge problem since crafting isn't the main focus of the game, and more likely a menu you will look through every-so-often just to check if you gathered enough items to fill a certain criteria. CONCLUSION That's pretty much it. I think this may be the longest review I've ever written, but I think SoG deserves it. At the time of writing this, I'm only 2 hours into the game and I can't wait to see what I can uncover next. This is truly an amazing RPG/Adventure game.I will update the review throughout the early access process and with my advancement of the game. Thank you for giving the time to read this review, and I'll see you in Grindea.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								Secrets of Grindea is a top down adventure game that immediately reminds me of the Legend of Zelda series in it's blend of combat and puzzles. While still an early access game at the time of writing, there is more than enough content to justify the fifteen dollar price tag. With an easy to learn combat system and the lack of distinct classes, combat feels smooth and genuinely fun, as one would hope a game with the term "grind" in the title would boast. Likewise, the characters are for the most part interesting, if perhaps not always particularly memorable.The characters of Grindea tend to alternate between totally forgettable and completely memorable. Your talking loot bag, appropriately named Bag, your close friend Luke, and your somewhat obnoxious rival Marino all manage to establish themselves with completely memorable characteristics - Bag is very cynical and sarcastic, with what appears to be an mix of disinterest and dislike for all things not labeled Very Rare Loot. Luke, meanwhile, is a hardworking powerhouse of a boy, but isn't particularly bright. Marino is a rich, bratty noble, and while that's not particularly deep as a character, he does a good job of making it memorable. On the other hand, quest giver Quinton, a couple of clearly reoccuring, almost Team Rocket - esque thugs, and even the player character's own father all seem to have virtually no personality. In the interest of fairness, these characters haven't recieved nearly as much screentime as Bag, but the problem is that the charcters I found memorable made themselves memorable from the first meeting, whereas all of these less memorable characters have appeared at least twice and still have yet to make any sort of impact on me.Combat in Grindea, as I mentioned above, is a very easy concept to grasp, if a little hectic in practice. The Z key is your basic melee attack with whatever is equiped to your weapon slot, X raises your shield, and the A,S,D,F,C, and V keys all bind to the various special attacks and spells you pick up over the course of the game. This means that a solid blend of melee and magical combat is more than plausible, although the effort to make that blend work is probably more than a strictly melee or magical style. That being said, the only character I've made so far is very focused to the ice branch of magic, and so I am unable to comment on how balanced the various skills are as of now. Despite this, it's worth repeating that the combat system itself is very enjoyable, and the more polished parts of the game are an immense pleasure to play.However, it's also worth repeating that this is an early access game, and it began to become extraordinarily obvious when I was coming close to the end of the story mode content simply because the majority of the major fights became seriously unbalanced towards solo players. Perhaps it becomes less of a headache with coplayers in the mix, but one particularly noteworthy boss fight required me to keep putting damage on the boss while at the same time destroying remarkably resilient minions that were spewing poisonous gas across the battlefield. Forget to put enough pressure on the boss, and he will fully heal his minions and render them invulnerable until you go back to putting damage on the boss himself. As a solo player, the task was almost too much for me to handle, and I was only able to scrape by thanks to the points I'd put into my summonable snow golem. I don't take issue with the idea behind the boss fight, but it's more than evident that the devs have yet to find an appropriate balance that challenges a group of playeres and still remains manageable for solo players.That fight notwithstanding, coming closer to the end of story mode also saw a lot of interesting puzzles and challenges spring forth. There's a dungeon in which the changing of the seasons is required to open up different paths to progress, and there's a sequence closer to the end of the existing content in which a teleportation power from earlier is used to cross elaborate labrynths of cannons, using mirrors and timed launches to get across. While difficult, I found myself enjoying the sequence, and look forward to seeing how the puzzles might further develop with the release of future content.All in all, Grindea is a fun game that is definitely worth the price, despite it's glaring flaws, and it shows a lot of potential in where it can go from here. While not yet finished, it's a very enjoyable product and looks to be a fantastic game in the making.

content:
Posted: April 14, 2016
Early Access Review
								Really great game where grinding is a must but I don't mind it, probably because of the art style and the fact that it looks and feels like an old zelda game (Link to the past comes to mind for me). From the bush and crate cutting to the movement and pixel art it all feels very old school zelda which is amazing. On top of that add some great dialogue between npc's and even some zelda references and you got Grindea. The crafting system is really great too, grinding for items to make even better gear feels very rewarding. And an unlimited bag space means collect every sword, hat, shield, and card you can because ♥♥♥♥ it, why not? Bottom line, if you loved old school zelda games on the SNES and NES you'll love grindea and it gets even better when you play with friends.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2016
Early Access Review
								TLDR; Modernized Zelda from SNES days. Quality game design. Great Story. Multiplayer is very rewarding. 9/10(Only because it is incomplete as of yet).Long Version: This is a great little game! The art and music are awesome, the gameplay is simple to grasp yet tough to master, and the characters and story make "Secrets of Grindea" shine! There is a great mixture of action, crafting, and minigames to keep your experience varied and entertaining. In it's current state(4/20/2016) it offers about 15-20 hours of playtime through the main story, not including replays and the arcade survival mode. I have nothing but good things to say about this game and look forward to it's completion. Played with a friend you will find yourself wanting for more!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Finally an Indy that gets it RIGHT.  They have captured the old SNES games 100%.  No cheese, no lameness, no clunky interface, no tryhard here,, just a great title.  My only problem with Zelda III and Secret of Mana is that both games had an ending, they were so good.  Those games are timeless, and the graphics hold through even today due to the art style etc...   Secrets of Grindea continues in thier tradition and I just love it, there are a few throwback references but they don't overdo it (like a lot of games do).   Even though it's still Beta, early access, etc... I hope they continue to produce content in the form of DLC forever.  Thanks. Gameplaywise, the controller support is spot on, it is very alt tab friendly, the game is only 380Mb, so will probably work on any computer out there.  (I'm playing on a tablet, Surface Pro 3..).  Go for it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
Early Access Review
								What an incredible game!Secrets of Grindea is a story-driven game (With phenomenal RPG elements!) where you can customize your character's appearance, skills, and talents. While the mechanics are simple to grasp, there are many unique bosses and mobs that require certain nuances to accomplish.The leveling system works out relatively well. It never feels like an over the top grind (hah) until about halfway through, where it suddenly starts to feel like it takes longer to level based upon the monster EXP.Perhaps my only real complaint about the game lies in the skill system. They've set it up so that you get silver and gold spell points, where you spend so many silver points before you may only place gold points to further level up a skill. After spending 17 hours in the game, I've only been able to get one skill all the way up with gold points, as you only receive one point every few levels.Still, you can completely customize your hotkeys, and they made it quite easy and intuitive. Though it is early access, they've already thought of many convenience things that other games miss: equipping cosmetic items for free, pets that increase stats, NPCs that have witty responses, etc.It's rare you find an unfinished game that leaves you thinking about it even while you're in the middle of working, exercising, and trying to sleep. I'm only sad it isn't finished! 9.5/10TL;DR - Buy this game. I'd regret not trying it. Smooth graphics, intuitive gameplay, conveniency in the game, and some light humor! Totally worth the price.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
Early Access Review
								TL/DR;Pros  - Spiritual successor to older ARPG titles (Secret of Mana/Star Tropics/A Link to the Past)  - Solid build customization and choices that change gameplay a lot  - Responsive Controls, Xbox controller works fine off the hop with zero third party software necessary  - Good Humor  - Good Multiplayer Experience and Customization  - Decent Musical Score  - Fairly difficult compared to modern games (Tough but fair, it's not quite "Nintendo Hard" but close)Cons  - Default keybindings can be hard on hands, probably want a controller unless you want to custom keybind.  - Menu slightly unintuitive at first  - Crafting doesn't seem to be covered at all in the first few hours or so  - Game is incomplete, some areas not accessable even early on, does not impact current gameplay though.It's pretty decent, only have 3 hours in so far though.   Like it says on the tin it definitely captures the spirit of Secret of Mana/A Link to the Past/Star Tropics. However it also adds in some nice new shiny features, the biggest one being build customization. I guess the closest comparison on the build system would be something like Skyrim or Kingdoms of Amular: Reckoning (as in non linear, pick whatever you want but there's still progression within each).   The controls are responsive however being an old goat I got hand cramps after the first hour and switched to Xbox 360 controller and enjoyed it a lot more after that (could still probably be solved with some manual rebinding). It's a little quirky to get used to the menu controls being that it behaves exactly like an old SNES title (no mouse, nested menus button press down and back up).  The dialogue is pretty funny, it has a lot of fourth wall humor often poking fun at itself and the genre. So far the score is decent but I'm only a few hours in.  I got a few friends to buy it and we've been playing together and having a blast, the steam integration makes this super easy. You can choose whether to scale the leveling or not which seems nice but hasn't actually been tested by me yet, we're all pretty low level so I didn't see the point. Also loot options can be customized I didn't bother though as round robin seemed to work, the nice thing is it seems that if you haven't got a chest yet in story mode and another player opens it up you still get it. It doesn't seem to scale the enemies much in 2 player, so you can sort of cheese some content by ressurecting a downed player, but you have to time it properly so I guess it's not the end of the world. Oh and other than that, there's no healing in the game beyond picking up a certain drop (sort of like old Mega-Man games). I was nervous buying on early access but feel that this genre was worth the investment, we don't see many and I was pleasently suprised by the quality of this early access and the decent amount of difficulty in the game, you'll probably die quite a bit, but it's pretty fair. So yeah would recommend.EDIT: After playing with 3 the difficulty does indeed scale, though perhaps not enough I removed the con from the list.

								edit: editing this review because the fanbase of this game seriously cannot handle anything that isn't blatantly positive.I don't recommend this game. That's all you're going to get.What's important to note here is that I had a pretty in-depth review about this game, that could have informed consumers before purchase, and now I don't. Now it's just  a thumbs down because the community around this game are irritating and I feel that offering any kind of information about it, is supporting it in some kind of way. Every time I logged into steam and saw a message notification, it was about this game - someone whining about how I didn't review it right, or I just "suck" at it, or - my favourite - am somehow obligated to continuously update a review on a game I do not play anymore.So yeah, don't buy it because I don't like it because reasons.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
Early Access Review
								The Secrets of Grindea is a neat little game reminiscent of ARPG's like Secret of Mana and Ys: Oath in Felghana. The combat is fluid, more so than that of Legend of Zelda and equipping a Two-Handed weapon does not take away your ability to use a shield. The character sprites are amazing and dynamic, you rarely find an NPC doing nothing physically as most have a nice implemented action to make themselves seem more lifelike. Ones that you find in-game that do this range from flipping their hair, kicking a wagon, turning a crank, and even sipping tea or sneezing. It makes the world come to life more and each NPC has their own individual character portrait to show that they aren't just faceless boring no-name people in the lush world of Grindea.Skills take another aspect of the game in that they ARE diverse but there isn't a lot of them. Your main weapons will consist of a sword, either one-handed or two-handed and that is the limitation of your weapons. You will find others such as a bow and arrow while exploring but that is just a side weapon which left me wanting a more diverse weapon system. I wish there were more weapons such as a double headed spear that an enemy NPC had or even another skill branch for the bow and arrow but alas there is none. The world of Grindea itself is nice and all the sprites are beautiful and amazing, however that does not excuse the games limited exploration. Throughout my playthrough I had tried to explore numerous pathways to other parts of the world only to be stopped by an invisible wall and a text box saying. "You can't go there! That part of the game is not yet implemented." This kills exploration as there is only on path you can take instead of being able to explore the world as you like which leads me wanting more.For the price of 14.99$ this game is not bad, and is actually amazing. I just wish that there was more diversity in weapons and one pet peeve of mine is that equipment (such as gloves, shoes, or armor) does not show to change the characters clothes as if appearing invisible. That being said however, this game is not worth 15$ but IS worthy of your time as the world of Grindea is still being made, hopefully once finished it will be worth its expensive price.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm just playing for 2 hours, still I can say it's one of the best game I played in a while.As the name "Grindea" already implies, the gameplay is kind of grindy, but in a very innovative way. Every monster you can find in the world of Grindea has a few possible drops, which can be gathered to craft new equipment or sold to make money and therefore buy new equipment. These drops are listed in some kind of codex but unless you find them, they are blackened out. Besides that there are also very rare cards which drop only once and improves your characters abilities permanently. These two features provide a lot of motivation randomly hunting monsters for their loot while following the main storyline on the side. It's almost a pokemon-like feeling where you try to complete your pokedex.As I said, I haven't played much, but till now the story is pretty basic stuff. Starting in a small village, doing a test to finally become whatsoever and heading out to great adventures. This is not necessarily a bad point, because you still keep track of the story, even if you skip some dialogues. The dialogues on the other side are quite funny and self-ironic. They make fun of some very stale RPG-cliches, like the bottomless bag of the game's main character.The main story holds up with some big boss battles, which are more or less challenging, depending on how much you grind on the side. If a boss can drop unique loot, the battle can also be repeated at any time. As far as I discovered, the game also provides some side-activities like fishing or treasure-hunting. The game's skill system allow to spend an active skillpoint in melee, magic or supportive and a passive skillpoint in general, melee or magic on each levelup. There are some skills that aren't implemented yet, because the game is still in early access. Nevertheless there are plenty available skills which can be combined freely. Every skill can be charged up to unleash a more powerful attack, which variates based on the amount of skillpoints put into a single skill. All in all the skill-system provides a wide range of different gaming-styles.Also, there is an arcade mode, where you have only one life to conquer a randomly generated world. Everytime you die, you start all over again in a newly generated world. But there are some unlockable permanent advantages.Summary: Buy the game! Also I'm sorry for possible language mistakes.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you like: The Legend of Zelda: A Link to the Past, Final Fantasy (Any), or Chrono Trigger... You will LOVE this game. I've been losing hope in new and upcoming games lately, but purchasing this game is more than worth it. I would have paid twice as much to own this work of art... AND ITS NOT EVEN FINISHED! Me and my brother played this game for about 7 hours straight when we bought it... (and we really don't have that kinda time anymore..) Needless to say, I will be on the edge of my seat each and every time they patch or update this game.This has all the RPG elements you could want. The real-time battle system is amazing. The skill trees and talent trees are superb. I love how the games characters take the time to make fun of itself. It's a serious game that doens't take itself too seriously (does that make sense?). I LOL at the dialogue often and actually want to see what each NPC has to say.The quests are fun and simple, but some are actually challenged for even a season RPG player to figure out.You will not regret spending a penny on this game! I promise you that. Enjoy. P.S to the developers - You guys rock... thank you SO much.. I've been waiting for a game that rivals The Legens of Zelda: A Link to the Past for so long... and yes I did just compare the two... I know what I said.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								I think this game is RIGHT down my alley. Unfortunatly, I have a couple of opinions :/ First of all, I think that pets should be able to help out in fights. Second, I think that Mages are a little OP. Third, there should be SOME form of regen like Health Potions sold at the Alchemy Shop, or some kind of Spell that restores health. Forth, Boars are insanly difficult and frustrating to battle considering they are incredibly fast and deal heavy damage, so you cant easily take them down without heavy damage. It doesn't really help that you have to perfectly time a Quick-Block. Fifth, I found an easy way to exploit the fact that you can cut off the attack recharge by Quick-Blocking. For example, if I were to Attack and Block really quickly alternating, i can attack twice a second and deall about 400 damage per second. I also used a whole lot of differant things that i could label as a little broken. First, Phillip (what I call the adorable little snow monster), I want to know whether or not i shoul consider him broken. I decided to max out Phillip and now hes practically like a second me (^-^) I'll add more later, but for now, I'd love to see Boar nerfing, and Health Potions in Story Mode.

content:

Early Access Review
								Early Access: I stumbled upon this game casually browsing steam and immediatly thought the game looked awesome at face value.  I got pretty excited when I saw that this game had a demo (including the multiplayer I might add), I played the demo for about 3 hours with and without a friend, and it hooked me the moment I stepped out into startington.  The music is top tear, the pixel art is astounding, the gameplay is crisp and challenging, and the game world has been the first to charm me this much since The Legend of Zelda Windwaker.  So far, I LOVE this game.  The game doesn't take it self very seriously, but there is still loads of meaning behind what you are doing in a world you actually care about, I want to catch every fish, get every pet, complete every quest, collect every item, and I want to be there to watch the story unfold.  Play this game with a friend and have so much fun that 6.5 hours go by like 60 minutes.  Devs if you keep this up, the game will marvel even it's inspirations (Secret of mana SNES) and (A Link to the Past SNES)  I would 100% reccomend this game right now, even if it's unfinished what has been here so far has been totaly worth the $15, grab a friend or 3, or play solo!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
Early Access Review
								High quality action rpg fun with a lot of nostalgia tossed in aswell. There really isn't enough I can say about this game, the multiplayer is crafted perfectly, with drop in/out features enemy difficulty increasing with each additional player not just increases in attributes but additional skills for bosses etc. Very indepth character leveling, allows you to create and mold your hero as you please, so you can find your perfect build. The story mode is probably about 50 percent complete, by the time i reached the end i was really yearning for more. There are tons of collectibles and several mini games including pets. Perfect game for the kind of person that loves additional content after the story, especially those who enjoy some grinding.For those tired of playing in the story, there is a very well crafted arcade mode that is of course also multiplayer and has almost infinite replayability. The real seller with this game though is the combat, which takes you back to old school SNES 2D top-down games like Link to the past and Secrets of Mana, but it is so much more then that. Once you find a build you enjoy whether you're just sitting back grinding enemies or facing the highest difficulty challenges, time just flies by.As you can tell I highly recommend this game. There is a demo available which definitely gives you enough of a taste of the game to understand my high praise.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
Early Access Review
 First impressions so far:  Secrets of Grindea is a really good game so far. The battle system reminds of the good times with Secret of Mana and A Link to the Past, the overall look recalls the feeling of Golden Sun and Chrono Trigger. Got the chills when I got out of town to explore the world. A good sign.tl;dr It's Nice. A bit of obnoxious nitpicking: - The portraits of the characters (in dialogues) may be not anyones taste. Sadly it isn't mine. (For example, the overworld sprite of the bag is awesome, but in the dialogues it loses it's magic.)- The Soundtrack so far is reaaally good, except for the first 14 seconds of the Evergrind City music, the first time you get there for the collectors exams. Something about it sounds wrong.

Early Access Review
								Secrets of Grindea is an homage to old school hack'n slash RPGs with multiplayer support for up to 4 players. I can't wait for this game to be finished and I would definitely recommend anyone to show some love for the developers by either purchasing the game or at least trying out its Demo.tl;dr I absolutely love Secrets of Grindea, can't wait for the game to be finished!

content:
Posted: February 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								TLDR; IT'S A GREAT FREAKIN GAME, YOU SHOULD DEFINITELY GET IT, LIKE NOW.This is truly one of those "hidden and unpolished gems". The game has this beautiful yet nostalgic art that just sucks you right into it. If you like intense combat that actually requires you to stay on your toes at all time, I really recommend this game. Even though it is an early access game, and that a lot (if not the majority of EA games) just aren't worth it, trust me on this one, this one really is.Pros:- Even though it's an ea game theres at least 5-10 hours of gameplay in the story mode so far.- Beautiful artwork.- Engaging combat system, with a variety of classes/skills that will make you wanna play it for a second time, just to test them out.- The story itself is fairly interesting and you'll most likely have a good laugh every now and then.- A big variety in the monsters and bosses, most of them function in different ways, making the game more interesting and not repetitive. - You can play with up to 4 friends, choosing whichever character you've saved. (There's I believe, 9 save slots atm)- Once you've played through whats been released in the story mode, you can just jump over to the arcade mode, which is sort of like a rougelike mode, which is super fun and addictive.- There is also a crafting system where you can craft weapons and armors.- There's a pet system, as for now it is pretty useless, but it is fairly fun to play around with.Cons: - It's an unfinished game, you will get to the point where there is no more content story wise and at that point you will be crying, begging for more.- I don't know if it's meant to be, but the crafting system is pretty useless in the arcade mode, since you never get enough materials to actually craft anything.- There's not that huge of a variety in items. There's a few for each class and so on, but after a few playthroughs the items will be a bit repetetive.Overall, if you like rpg style games, killing monsters, completing quests, fighting epic boss battles and taming crazy rabbits, then this game is definitely for you. I rate it 10/10.

content:
Posted: April 21
Early Access Review
								There is already enough there to justify a purchase, even if progress is slow.Character building is flexible.  Control is tight.  Boss fights are SNES-era multi-stage endeavors.  It's easy to see how it would take a small team a long time to make this content.You can check out their blog and judge for yourself whether they're on a proper pace.  There's even a free demo.I wouldn't expect a 100% finished game this year, but we already have a 100% playable and fun SNES-style game that looks 60-70% finished content-wise.  The quality and variety is competitive with old-school SNES ARPGs, and this is all coming from a much smaller team than who was making similar games in the 90s.  It's a great mix of nostalgia with enough innovation to make it their own.  They are maintaining a steady pace and consistency of quality so far.It isn't humanly possible to do it much faster, and if you want a complete game fast, you can hold your money instead of your breath when it comes to this title.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								TL;DR: Great game but slow progress. Recommended but see this as an investment, not a direct consumption item.For a game that has been an on going project for this many years there are certain expacations to be made. However seeing it being an early access game made by a very small team some criticisim can be made and some can't. But that's the point of reviewing. You give critique so the creator can be better. The beauty for us gamers is that developers are like wine or whiskey. They are either good and becomes better, they are good but falls hard due to arrogance and godlike complex or they never were good to begin with. The devs of SoG are hopefully the first type.Now enough of that and unto the game.The graphics are smooth and fantastic, for being 2D Spirites. That is however nothing bad as they simply tap into a bit of retro or nostalgia, depending on your age. For reference it's nostalgia for me. As I started this game it felt like playing a new Zelda game. A World to explore and you as the hero. The graphics help this mindset as you travel across the land and my god is the scenery gorgeues. Even with the limited graphics of 2D spirites they make everything flow smoothly and with an almost seamless action. The particles created by the various spells and skills as well as the various stages of boss fights make this game very good. During the harder difficult I died once due to the fact that I stopped and had to process I went from a Zelda-esque game to a Touhou level bullet hell. It was beautifulThe sound and music of the game aids the nostalgic/retro feeling and the sound effects made when you cast a spell or use a skill is quite satisfying. There is no lack of audio feedback on what's going on in this game. You will know when the enemy is about to charge you or a boss is starting a massive barrage of onslought. The feedback you get as a player in this game becomes even more valuable as you play on the harder difficulty when the bosses can go from "oh look a large quantity of bullets" to "This went from casual to hardcore bullet hell real fast...."As for the gameplay and it's mechanics I'm happy to say that it all feels fantastic. The controls respond as expected and the game runs smoothly. It lacks any need to have a beast of a machine. This is a game I have played during lunch hours on my work and those machines could be from last decade. The mechanics are well thought and well implemented into this game. It's easy to plan ahead on how you want to combat an enemy or a boss as the various types of attacks have easy and memroable patterns to learn. The fact that you also can easily switch mid-game on how you want to play makes it a nice setup for various combinations of attacks. It does however cost some money but it's worth it if you want to experiment.The game truly makes a good claim on old grinding games. It will become a massive grindfeast if you want to. I spent a good 10+ hours farming for various cards in the game, they are used to get passive boosts. The various mechanics in how you grind with combat can go from boring to a meditative set of moves. If you enjoy grinding that is.Overall the game works so good I really WANT the developers to finish the game but as I mentioned earlier in my TL;DR. This is to be the equivelent of a stock market investment. It may or may not yield profit in the end. Only time will tell. So far however, I've earned back my money spent in hours so for me this game was quite a good "bang for the buck" deal.

content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								While this game is still a work in progress, for what i have been able to do, this game is epic :DDialogue-ish stuffit has comedy, and stuff that makes sense. +9/10some comedy get's repeated too much, ie bag and fairy talking -2/10gameplaysince this game is a work in progress, im surprised how well it works. Boss battles were fun, just the right difficulty (my opinion, don't judge me XD) , which is when you die like, 3 times and then you beat the boss, or you farm for EXP (or grind) , and i love how they give you side quests to make it less linear! +10/10some quests are very repetitive, but theres not much to vary that kind of thing. -2/10graphics and art stuffah yes, an RPG adventure game. I personally think they should always be detailed, but cartoon-like or pixel-ish, and that's what we got. +8/10sadly though, lots of games accomplish this but it takes a lot of work to do art -1/10storya treasure hunter being his dad and wanting to be like him? ok story +7/10not too original -2/10varietytwo game modes!!! arcade and story! in arcade you basically have to go through a bunch of floors and kill monsters, and you can expand your home area to get really cool features! in story, it's... a story. fighting, questing, buying, and rage await! 10/10i do not have a problem -0/10awards-great for steam early access +8/100-solid, fun game for a affordable price +5/10087/100so buy it now!!!! or not... (cries in the corner of the room) XDretail: $15

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								(This review is based solely on the Story mode)This is an extremely promising 2D ARPG early access game that I absolutely adore. It is by no means close to being finished but it has an incredibly solid foundation. The first thing I need to mention is the art style is phenomenal and the game has one of my favorite soundtracks of any game out there. As I'm writing this review, my character is in the Flying Fortress just so I can listen to the music. The music gives me Final Fantasy vibes that I love. Let me also mention that the art in this game is awesome. The game is full of color and it's a beautiful game to look at.In terms of gameplay, there are many choices to be made. There are skill sets for 1H or 2H weapons and the magic is divided into fire, ice, earth, and air (which should be called lightning...). There are no classes so you can mix and match between all of these sets (For example, you can be a 2H user that also specializes in ice spells. If you freeze an enemy, you are guarenteed your next physical attack to crit). So far, there are 2 dungeons in the game that both have very strong themes and art styles. There is not a single part of this game I dread going through. I loved Tales of Symphonia but I HATED some of those dungeons/temples (especially the sewers, oh god). Let me also mention that the second dungeon has a mechanic involving changing seasons that I have never seen before in any game. Watching the whole room change colors is quite the thing to see. My only issue with the dungeons are that they are too short. I WANT MORE.-There are 6 notable bosses in this game and they are all designed very well each offering very different strategies to conquer them.-Each type of enemy has a small chance to drop a card which gives your character small permanent bonuses (5% discount at shops, Atk/MAtk/Def buffs, AtkSpd and CastSpd buffs, etc)-"Farming" is very easy in this game. If you kill a group of enemies, stick around for about 2 more minutes fighting enemies and the spawn rate at that location will increase like crazy. There's a room in the toy factory that will spawn endless amounts of presents for you to kill repeatedly. I probably did it for a solid 30-45 minutes and it was great!-This game also features Arcade mode which is essentially a rogue-like version of the game. It's pretty darn hard but fun I suppose. I haven't played it enough for the purpose of this review though.I'm looking forward to seeing more updates for this game. Not sure if you want to buy it yet? No biggie, PLAY THE DEMO! Thanks for reading! I will update this review once more updates come out.

								okay secrets of grindea is a great game for the content that is in already and more to come plus an arena mode that works like a rogue like with progression but the story is also really fun in the game you basicly play as a young collector who just passed a test and now you go out on adventure collecting stuff and fighting bosses the gameplay is that you have a shield and sword and skills you can use to attack and the shield to block if you bllock at the last second with your shield than your shield takes less damage and their attack gets canceled it is a cool mechanic there are no healng items but if you die you can respawn in the same room making it challenging and fun without having to do stuff all over again the puzzles are fun because at first they are confussing but if you figure it is sadisfieing and the bosses are amazing most of them are hard but than you feel even better when you beet them also you have classes so you can be a mage a one hand swords man or a two and swordsman giving you choice so this game gets a 9/10 would totaly play again

content:
Posted: September 11, 2015
Early Access Review
								I don't really know how to describe this game other than, "Strangely Satisfying".Yes this game is all about grinding (sort of self-evident by the title) but the grinding is actually pretty fun, You get a really wide range of attacks and abilities to use so you can really customize your combat style to your preferences. The game does unfortunately seem to be lacking a little bit in terms of character customization, but that's not a terribly bad thing, just something I wish would be improved upon. In fact I'd even say this game sort of handles like some of the old-school The Legend of Zelda games, except with more RPG elements to it. Plus, as someone who generally couldn't care less for dialogue, the dialogue in this game is actually pretty good. I actually laughed at a few parts and rarely found myself skipping through dialogue. Not to mention I think it's pretty clear the devs have some real passion for this game. You can really see all the hard work, love & care that went into this game.The only downside is that updates are unbelievably slow and infrequent.I can't really think of anything else to add that might convince people, but seriously, just buy it. I'm almost certain that if you're already interested, you'll enjoy it. However if you know this isn't your kind of game, why are you even here?

Early Access Review
								Brief:Do you like zelda games, top down exporler games, 8bit rpg story games,rougelike games if yest to any of those get this game.Graphics:The graphic are a great form of 8 bit style of the game, and the music is so spot on its perfect. They have such a huge varity of objects and animations that make this game look so good.GamePlayI have followed this game the day they it was on there site. I loved every mintue of there demo that i bought three copies, because the best part i think about this game is that its full 4 player online supported game. Exploering and boss fights are the best with friends and that ways it stands as one of my favorite games.
