number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								**This review is coming from a pure single-player experience** (there is multiplayer)I have done all of the story mode content there is to do at this time, minus collectibles, as of version 0.600amigo.Pros:-Fun combat, lots of skills and perks. You can respec for a doable in-game fee. Smooth and fluid animation.-Multiplayer, which I did not try out. This can be done in the story mode and arcade mode.-The environments are awesome, the character artwork could be better, and the music is good, but nothing I see myself humming to.-Many cameos from other video games. Zelda, RE4, Honeydew, to name a few.-There's a stable version and a "frontline" version. Pretty self explanatory. The latter has more frequent updates (every few weeks) the former every month or two, from my understanding.Cons:-The amount of monsters you have to kill and the many hours it takes to get a drop does not line up with an items rarity most of the time. It is not unheard of to spend 4-8 hours killing the same monster all to get a drop that is probably not better than what you already have JUST so you can work towards 100% completion. This is never a requirement, but the cards you can get in particular offer small permanent bonuses, and it can take you anywhere from 30 minutes to 8 hours to find the one that you want.-It's short. But the game's not done yet. The current story can be done in about 4-6 hours. Getting collectibles could get you another 10-20 hours, depending on your luck. Question is, do you want those mostly mediocre drops bad enough to spend all that time?-Arcade mode as a single player is quite a challenge. I usually opt for the harder options in video games like Kingdom Hearts on Critical but this mode is hard from the get go if you are alone. I would like to see some scaling in difficulty to make it more doable (maybe there already is, and I just suck.) But if you're looking for a challenge, you've got it here. An option to turn down the difficulty would be nice though.These problems can be easily remedied with time, however. The creators are friendly and interactive with their community, and they post frequent updates.So the question is, do I recommend this game? Is it worth the current price of $15.00?Yes it is. For the amount of playtime I got out of it, for the potential of what it can become, and for the multiplayer, which I didn't even touch, which is sure to add many hours. If nothing else, follow this game. Come back to it later. For an avid RPG fan, this is a game to watch out for.

								What can I say? I didn't think I would enjoy it near as much as I actually did. I mean, for a 14.99 Beta I expected some grumps, bumps and bugs but this is an extremely polished early access. There are zones you can't enter, sure, but the combat, story and characters are well rounded and feel complete. I was also extremely happy with the level of difficulty that came with some of the puzzles and bosses. It was a very lovely weekend diversion that I will be constantly revisiting for  more content.In one word? Omghappynostalgiagleechallengingexcitingrelaxingmmfgoodnesshighlyrecommend.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I had pre-ordered this way back when it first started pre-orders. I think this was two years ago? At the time the game only had about an hour of gameplay if you 100% everything. Being a person that understands what early-access is I decided to give the game a while before coming back and trying it again. Now the game has evolved quite a bit since I last played. They have added on a few features, and the story is far more progressed... and it's awesome. The combat is fun, the dungeons are very well scripted and planned out, and the bosses are exciting and challenging. I'm happy to say the multiplayer is also very well done. I have spent a few hours playing with my wife with little to no issues (One time she couldn't see a boss for some reason)One of the neat aspects about Grindea is actually the way grinding works. If you stay in one place and kill things for a bit you will see that enemies will begin to spawn more and more frequently. This allows for quick leveling and farming for items. It also means that grinding gets more challenging in that spot. It is well worth it for more than just leveling, enemies can also drop special cards that give your character permanent stat boosts.I could go on but I think one would really have to play the game to get a good impression. Luckily they have a demo although I don't know how up to date it is compared to the actual game.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is what you might consider a baby review. What I mean is I only do reviews on initial playthrough and how long a game keeps me interested. Overall Rating: 5/5This game so far has won the "Keep me playing Longest Award" by far. I am serious. Usually a game keeps my attention for .4 to 3.5 hours before I move on to another game or switch back to playing CS:GO. 19.4 hours before I am forcing myself to go play a few CS:GO Matches. That is insane. I beat the early access normal Story. Then ran some Arcade, which is so Rouge-Lite it made my heart hurt. I just had to keep going. Okay, so a bit of a breakdown. The Graphics are what you see. 16 bit love. The game play is a mixture of A Link To The Past, Secret of Mana, and some flair of it's own. Multiplayer is a bit laggy at times, but other than that it's fun as hell. I cannot recommend this game enough honestly. There are bugs, there are balancing issues, and I can accept that because the game is not complete. But that being said, I would play this incomplete game over 90% of the complete games avaliable right now. Buy this. Share this. Throw money at the Devs and expect nothing in return. Other than a brilliant game that is. If you are expecting me to go into further detail, you are missing the above sentence. Seriously... Buy this.

								I had pre-ordered this way back when it first started pre-orders. I think this was two years ago? At the time the game only had about an hour of gameplay if you 100% everything. Being a person that understands what early-access is I decided to give the game a while before coming back and trying it again. Now the game has evolved quite a bit since I last played. They have added on a few features, and the story is far more progressed... and it's awesome. The combat is fun, the dungeons are very well scripted and planned out, and the bosses are exciting and challenging. I'm happy to say the multiplayer is also very well done. I have spent a few hours playing with my wife with little to no issues (One time she couldn't see a boss for some reason)One of the neat aspects about Grindea is actually the way grinding works. If you stay in one place and kill things for a bit you will see that enemies will begin to spawn more and more frequently. This allows for quick leveling and farming for items. It also means that grinding gets more challenging in that spot. It is well worth it for more than just leveling, enemies can also drop special cards that give your character permanent stat boosts.I could go on but I think one would really have to play the game to get a good impression. Luckily they have a demo although I don't know how up to date it is compared to the actual game.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								Just made it through the story missions available, as well as a few side things. Gotta say this is really good. I dont usually buy into early access, But this shows a lot of potential. Solid music, good combat, and some pretty good humor make this a great time, and really makes me eager for future updates. There really isnt much to complain about here, but there are a few nitpicks. I noticed a few typos, picking up health orbs is a little annoying (as you need to stand right on top of them to collect them), some of the bosses need a bit of tweaking, and some of the characters artwork could be touched up a bit, maybe smoothed out a bit and varying the facial features, as many characters look similar. None of those nitpicks really take away from what you get here though, a fantastic look into what I hope will be an amazing finished product. If you're into games like the zelda series then this is a great pick for you. Thanks to the developers, you guys are doing a great job.

content:
Posted: August 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								Though in early access, this game is super entertaining. It brings back the feel of classic games like The Legend of Zelda, but with the added bonus of your friends tagging along. The story is fun, light, and there are many classic throwbacks that gamers will smile at as they play. Definitely worth investing in to help progress it to completion.Some more good things; there are a lot of reasons to continually fight spawning monsters, which makes farming experience worth it. From collecting new items, which help to craft better armor and weapons, to making the money, to just gathering xp to expand your skills. (Which there are many of.)The only downside I and my friend have found, is the magic abilities aren't as useful as the melee abilities. We both wanted to utilize the magic skills but we quickly realized just using our swords was easier and much much faster.This game is in development so I hope to see some changes to the magic abilities down the road.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Even though "Secrets of Grindea" is only in Early access at the moment, the little preview of what they have made so far has me looking forward to seeing more.This game look me back, oh the nostalgia of the old Action / Puzzler / Rpg's really got me remembering those game I once used to play when I was younger,  I used to spend hours just looking for that sword or hunting for the rare monsters! and even getting stuck on a puzzle (until I just gave up asked a friend if they got passed it and how they did it)For those wanting a good Rpg, puzzle, Action, Adventure game with a slice of nostalgia or just something different to play I would recommend this game! The game play is fun and engaging, the starting story line you get to see, gets you wondering what is coming next, the skill leveling gives you so many different ways to play, even the fishing! (something I hate in Games) is more like a mini game than a chore! I can't wait to see what else is to come in the later updates 10/10 from me  :)

content:
Posted: September 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								The charms and mannerisms of Zelda meet the colours and music of Pokemon, thrown together in a modern take on classic action RPG's.This game is godamn beautiful. A work of art, and I'm able to say this after hardly any time played. Infact, I bought it for myself, and then within 5 minutes had bought it for my partner and friends. Story Mode is great, the bosses are awesome and you actually see yourself getting better at the game as you play (amongst the thousands of deaths). SPOILER ALERT: Arcade Mode is also pretty awesome and the take on it is unique. You have a small town, and depending on how well you do fighting on the mountain, your town is improved.I would highly suggest this game even to those of you who perhaps haven't tried a game of this type before. 10/10

content:

Early Access Review
								Initial Review:This game reminds me of the snes rpgs but brings new mechanics to the forefront.  Its as many people have said about it early access however the devs been working on this game for 4 years from what people are saying in the forums and it shows through the quality of the game.Story mode from what I gather is still lacking about 6 hours in total however it only intends to get better :) and longer as they add more stuff in. as the development progresses I can only see the game getting better.Arcade mode satisfies my rogue dungeon crawling needs as you have 1 life to get through as far as you can get which is a good time killer if no time for story mode.Overall the game is very polished and I am glad to play this game as early as I did hope it gets only better :), because this game shows that the dev is very knowledgeable and very concern with quality.

Now classes there are none its all skill based and you can pick and choose how you want to play the game. content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								I LOVE THIS GAME!!! This is the first RPG game that i have plaued besides pokemon when i was younger.  The pixil art is great! Such small details are put into this! It took me 68 minutes to beat one of the first bosses, i kept dying and thats where the learning curve comes in, you start to notice the patterns of attack and adapt to them. I absolutely love the music too! And the colors, i just love green environments. This game reminds me of Sword Art Online, and the beginning is kind of like Hunter X Hunter if anyone has seen that. Oh and the characters are pretty funny, i literally laughed out loud when there were 2 thugs stopping me at a bridge and they came charging and i used a quick burst of lightning magic and they just fell flat on the ground XD Anyway ill give this game a....10/10!!

content:
Posted: August 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								After watching Day[9] play this on his live stream we couldn't wait to play. It's amusing dialog is hilarious to read through, and keeps the progression of the story fun enough to not want to skip to gameplay. The customization in fighting styles between my husband and I became evident right away. I dove into a two handed knight with fire damage, and lightening magic to power up my hits. He went into one handed with evasive skills, and speed. We are excited to see what more comes out of the game, as its hard to find co-ops that are so enjoyable in this style of play. Highly recommend!

content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								**This review is coming from a pure single-player experience** (there is multiplayer)I have done all of the story mode content there is to do at this time, minus collectibles, as of version 0.600amigo.Pros:-Fun combat, lots of skills and perks. You can respec for a doable in-game fee. Smooth and fluid animation.-Multiplayer, which I did not try out. This can be done in the story mode and arcade mode.-The environments are awesome, the character artwork could be better, and the music is good, but nothing I see myself humming to.-Many cameos from other video games. Zelda, RE4, Honeydew, to name a few.-There's a stable version and a "frontline" version. Pretty self explanatory. The latter has more frequent updates (every few weeks) the former every month or two, from my understanding.Cons:-The amount of monsters you have to kill and the many hours it takes to get a drop does not line up with an items rarity most of the time. It is not unheard of to spend 4-8 hours killing the same monster all to get a drop that is probably not better than what you already have JUST so you can work towards 100% completion. This is never a requirement, but the cards you can get in particular offer small permanent bonuses, and it can take you anywhere from 30 minutes to 8 hours to find the one that you want.-It's short. But the game's not done yet. The current story can be done in about 4-6 hours. Getting collectibles could get you another 10-20 hours, depending on your luck. Question is, do you want those mostly mediocre drops bad enough to spend all that time?-Arcade mode as a single player is quite a challenge. I usually opt for the harder options in video games like Kingdom Hearts on Critical but this mode is hard from the get go if you are alone. I would like to see some scaling in difficulty to make it more doable (maybe there already is, and I just suck.) But if you're looking for a challenge, you've got it here. An option to turn down the difficulty would be nice though.These problems can be easily remedied with time, however. The creators are friendly and interactive with their community, and they post frequent updates.So the question is, do I recommend this game? Is it worth the current price of $15.00?Yes it is. For the amount of playtime I got out of it, for the potential of what it can become, and for the multiplayer, which I didn't even touch, which is sure to add many hours. If nothing else, follow this game. Come back to it later. For an avid RPG fan, this is a game to watch out for.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I agree with many other reviewers beneath me in that Grindea is an engaging, bugless and smooth rpg that has a definite MMORPG feel with the optional rare items farming that I find incredibly relaxing. Pros - *Excellent 2-D graphics without being pixelated as seems to be the norm lately.*Responsive easy to learn controls that forgive mistakes but only to a point.*Crafting system makes even weak monsters seem worth killing.*Boss fights are genuinely epic and satisfying.Cons - *Crafting system starts out promising but the lack of items to make in later levels makes it feel gimmicky instead.*Lack of weapons in general makes battles feel too repetitive after awhile.*Replay value somewhat hindered in storymode by the increasing costs of changing your talent points, sometimes requiring 30 minutes to an hour of farming to try something new.All in all I'd say for an early access game this is terrific and if the developers could fix the above issues and perhaps double what is already in the beginning stages...It would be a good I would be willing to pay 40+ dollars for. It feels like an offline MMORPG with Zelda-esque vibes. Great game for relaxing and listening to tunes. I pray it gets better from here.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
Early Access Review
								Bought this game on a whim and I really glad I did.  Has some of the best elements from the old adventure rpg games from the past.  I reminds me heavily of the old SNES Link to the Past meets Secret of Mana.  Gives you the ability to chose your skill pattern as well as giving the option to repsec using ore.  I bougth this game today I a managed to squeeze in a little over an hour into.  The controls are really smooth and its really easy to go back and forth between skills.  I have not joined a Co-Op game yet, but I think the single player mode is fun in itself.  I would recommend this game for anyone who is a fan of classic feel adventure RPGs of the past.  The only negatives I would say is some of the names of the characters you run into.  Could use some work there but that's only me trying to find one this wrong with this game.  Really good game.  Looking forward to put some more hours into it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2016
Early Access Review
								(Current review is for version .650SUMMARY:  A love letter, homage, and parody of classic Nintndo-style action RPGS filled with features, character and customization.  Must-support and must-buy for fans of classic action-RPG and crafting.  Even in Early Access it's impressive.Let's get the bad out of the way - this game is Early access, and as of late 2016 I don't expect it to be finished for over a year.  That being said, if you love top-down action RPGs with crafting, you probably should be supporting this anyway, but if you want, read my review.Secrets of Grindea manages a difficult job.  It is a love letter to classic top-down button-mashing action RPGs Nintendo was famous for, but also packs in the "best" features of many games.  It is an homage to all those games, without limiting itself.  Finally it's a parody that's not mocking, but affectionate - and the parody elements even work into the plot.The best comparisons I've found are Dungeonmans and Starbound, games that took their time, knew their subject, evolved, and turned into something amazing.In the game, you are a young Collector in the world of Grindea, your aim is to collect artifacts and equipment.  The game offers:* Highly customizable skills.  You can focus on two kinds of weapons, four kinds of magic, and support skills.  You can also tweak "talents" that affect how abilities and skills function together.  Each of these abilities can also be leveled up, improving and changing how they work.  Build a combat maniac who mashes stuff with a hammer, a summoner surrounded by friends, a dashing dodging ninja.  It's up to you.* Simple but effective crafting with depth.  Find enough stuff, make stuff is how it goes, but you'll need to explore and experiment to discover what unknown ingredients are needed.  Fortunately things you encounter that can be used are specially tagged.* Choose your equipment. Weapons, hats, armor, accessories, and more all affect how your character functions. Power up your magic with a sorcerous chapeau, find boots that speed up your movement while you charge skills, or stick a pumpkin on your head. You can also choose items to be "cosmetic," changing appearance while you benefit from an equipped item.* Plenty of quests and sidequests and extras.  There's always something to do in Grindea, with plenty of rewards.  Don't forget to return to people you've talked to before.* The fun of the grind.  If you want to max out your equipment, you're going to mash monsters. Grindea, however, makes it fun, with ways to increase spawns, meet tougher monsters, or refight bosses.  You can even tweak skills and equipment for maximum, fast grind. Farming is actually fun.* Lots to do.  Go fishing. Raise a pet. Find minigames.  Look for hidden treasure. Up your hat collection with Mister Fabulous. Grindea offers you many things to do depending on goals and mood.* A great visual style. The world's classic-cartoony not-quite-anime look is charming and appealing, the monsters have personality, the settings are colorful.* A great soundtrack. There's a classic game soundtrack here that sets the mood and is excellently composed.* Story and humor.  There's plenty of humor and an actual story (with some great twists) that's not all laughs. The game comes to life as well as making you laugh.* Two game modes.  You've got your usual adventure, but also the roguelike random adventure mode that lets you gradually build a character legacy and a town.* Optional co-op. On top of everything else, play with friends.Sound like a lot?  The game's staff also consists of three people as of this writing. It's pretty amazing what they've done since 2011.Just a reminder as of this writing it's early access.  The game is very fun, there's lots to do, but it's not done.Now who should get this if you're willing to go Early Access?* If you love old-school AARPGs you probably should just pick it up now to enjoy it and give feedback.* If you love looting and crafting and hunting up rare things and playing minigames, get it.* If the above review interested you.  This game hits a special sweet spot, it just "fits" some people.I picked it up and figured I'd check it out due to curiosity.  I played it for 2 hours before realizing how deep in I'd gotten.That might be the best reccomendation I can make.

content:
Posted: April 10
Early Access Review
								I played the whole game until the end of the "current beta" (Spoilers)While the game is rich there are a lot of things that really made this game a bad experience:Combat seems to offer a lot at first sight but after playing it has a lot of flaws. I did not suck at combat, i think i did pretty well, i also farmed nearly all cards, but during combat a always felt annoyed, they are a chore:- The deeper into the game the more unbearable the combat system becomes. At first everything is fine and plays decent, enemies have some advertised charge abilities and some require you to block or dodge.- Then suddenly the enemies start to kite like hell and abuse your 4 directional attack restrictions of your abilities by dodging diagonally all the time (Skycastle). Next you have the Snowball jugging guys in the snow-areas which throw nearly invisible projectiles at you.- The gift-box enemies just throw an infinite amount of bombs at you to create random area-denial which taunts you to respec your combat style to spells but this costs much gold- The season temple was ok, except for the hydra fight which shows what is the biggest problem for the remaining game: The game sets up a framework for combat, and then completely cripples this framework by denying you in all sorts of ways in order to create artificial difficulty.Good games create the challenge around the tools it hands to you, not by giving you good tools and then break them.The hydra either does Area denial in a much too small arena, makes you blind (what a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ design choice) or removes your ability to move responsively (ice-floor, even when you have the spiky boots) in a battle that requires evasion of charges, so you are fully dependend on your dodge ability, which makes the fight pretty easy again, as if the developer wants you to do things a certain way, like Apple. The fight vs the Winter-dude sucks because it has so much randomness and badly advertised attacks. I decide therefore to just gimp him by blocking the storm that was supposed to lure me the the opposite site of his long vincibility frame with the mushroom shield. This creates a blind-patch that boosted my crit by 25. That and a dmg-potion and he can be killed after two of his "i just wait 30s until you pass through my ice-maze that totally abuses the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ movement to damage you"-phases. Did i mention that diagonal movment isnt normalized? so you move Root of 2 faster when moving diagonally.The game has its zenit in the Crystal-cave- zone where every enemy and NPC is just designed to♥♥♥♥♥♥you off until you just skip them.There are Worms that create Area Denial patches everywhere that must be outwaited in order to take no dmg. Mushrooms create blinding fields if you vanquish them. Shell Monsters do a random charge-bounce thing that is so fast that it WILL hit you randomly... All this artificial crippling is shoved into your face one last time with the fight vs the Power-Flower in order to remind you why you hate this games combat.After that you are having the most annoying npc interaction of the game so far with a caveling that is scamming you obviously, but you have to follow through and at the end you are completely mocked, 2 minutes later the game ends.Other:- You cannot really try every skill without grinding loads of gold because there is a somewhat hefty fee required everytime you want to respec your points. There is no way of trying abilities without spending your sparse points into it, maybe save game manipulation, the descriptions are detailed though- The bag (your travaling companion) constantly patronizes you and is in general a scum-bag (pun anyone?). It comments on your inferiorness every time you die, which really feels discouraging because some battles are really badly implemented and always regards you as an incapable kid through the course of the game. I would throw this thing away immidiately if i was given the option.- While the Pixelart-Animation is wonderful and very fluid, the Background Artwork lacks some texturing at the snow and grass areas which make them feel like MS-Paint-Jobs. The Woods and Caves are gorgeous. The dialog-box-faces look strangely out of place and i wonder if they where made by a different artist

								So I really love the begining of this game. It was just perfect. Exactly what I was looking for and I had so much fun. Just perfectly blocking stuff to reflect it, dodging things by using Skills, trying to figure out some puzzles. It was so much fun.But since I started playing the Tai Ming - Part, I stoped enjoing the game. It's just boss fight, fight vs 1000 mobs where parrying is useless and you just have to run arround, followd by another boss fight, followd by a fight vs 1000 mobs and so on. It's just not that much fun in my opinion, and the outplay potential is pretty low there. Also one of boss of this Quest just is kinda anoying. It's basicly just like playing one of these japenes 2d dodge games. And I totaly hate them...I just hope that they woun't continue to make these almost only boss dungeons, because thats not what I bought this game for. Because there are tons upon tons of boss after boss games out there...So long term short: I loved the begining of the game, but I don't like how it's developing.Maybe my view onto this game is going to change with some upcoming dungeons and so on, but that's my current opinion on this game.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
Early Access Review
								This is what indie retro games is all about. Forget all those games you get in bundles that claim to be retro greatness, but they are really just posing behind 8 & 16 bit graphics but are missing all the greatness that those eras stood for. Those games try to make you buy their games based on your love for nostalgia. This one hit it on the money!!!!!Secrets of Grindea!!!! Oh yes, this game has done it all right. This is a game that brings back all the best memories from the classic era, games like Zelda for SNES, Secrets of Mana, and it takes what we loved in those games to a whole new level with modern additions and systems.The combat is awesome action RPG goodness. Hack and slash, cast spells, dodge, block, aim, it is all here and feels great, tight and responsive.The class system is that you can be anything you want. use any weapon, buy any skill from any school of magic. Boost defense, boost elements, boost crit, boost certain spell types and so on. Insane amount of depth with limitless combination of ways to build your character. You can also customize the way you look with different looking hats, shields, weapons that you find and equip throughout the game, its all visible, your hair and skin color and more is also selectable.Slash bushes, crates, vases, you know we all loved to do that and see what item is inside, could be nothing or something great. There is crafting, fishing and all kinds of other "jobs" that you can do in this game as well. It has multiplayer where friends can join you on your adventure online.This game has so much greatness and is only in EA. These Devs work hard and love what they are creating and it shows. If you really love retro gaming, you will buy this now!!! Stop buying the low quality crap that comes from greenlight for 10 games in a $1 bundle and put your cash down on something you will actually play, enjoy and be proud to own and say you paid for.

								I very, very, rarely. Ever make any review posts, heck may be first one on Steam spite I been using Steam for so long. I am glad I purchased this game and will have my partner purchase it as well once its fully released. If she wont, ill buy her it.

content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
Early Access Review
								Grindea is a 2D arpg: - With great humour,  - Noticable references that somehow don't feel out of place in the world - Good music - Great and relatable character - A simple yet deep and flexible combat system - Varied zones, and enemies with movesets that you need to learn in order to counter them (ala dark souls, sort of) - Beautiful and amazing level designs and artwork - Some of the best and most varied animation I've seen in most games (even the ones that use mocap! Even more than call of duty ghost's dogs and fish) - Very diverse and interesting bosses, some of which even ambush you so... DON'T WATCH A PLAYTHROUGH as it will most likely lessen the experience. AND THE LIST GOES ON AND ON AND ON AND ON and on and on a,,nd o,,, n ,,,,, If I was to name ONE flaw, (which isn't really a flaw) its that its not done yet. Although I'm personally pretty patient, this game is so amazing that its making me impatient!!Beware, its hard to get your health back after you take hits. So it may either be a very skillful game or a very slow one as you agro each enemy 1 by 1 or avoid/block multiple attacks repeatedly. Its a very hard game if you do not think about your tactics and just mindlessly wail on enemies.  But regardless, I highly recommend playing with a controller, as the game fully supports it and is much easier to work with compared to the keyboard and mouse. There is no voice acting from what I can see however the story is enthralling and very well written. Its well worth the read, so if you can, make sure to read the dialogue.Whoever wrote the scripts, make a book. I'll pay to proof read it no matter how many rewrites you do! In fact I am currently tossing my credit card at the screen with my bank details as we speak.Anyway theres a lot more to talk about but... TLDR; JUST GO BUY IT! BUY IT THEN BUY IT AGAIN SO YOU CAN PLAY WITH YOUR FRIENDS SINCE IT SUPPORTS 4 PLAYER CO OPP.S. If you can somehow, somehow resist the demonic levels of temptation then just keep it in mind for the full release and experience the complete package. As it stands right now though its still definitely worth buying even now. I haven't finished it yet and I've got over 5 hours so its certaintly got enough content,

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								EA Summary: Really polished encounters, controls, and a ton of fun.  Currently low on content (about 6-7 hours to do all main quests and side quests).  While I recommend this game, it is NOT worth $15 at this stage (9/1/2015).Detailed Pro's: The encounters (11/10!) in this game are incredibly well tuned and the clear highlight of this game.  There's no healing that I'm aware of, which means you will be challenged to learn each of these encounters as you die many, many times, similar to Super Meatboy or Dark Souls.  Like Meatboy, you will respawn instantly, and like dark souls, being greedy never pays off; slow and steady wins the race.  The world is also quite nice with beautiful pixel graphics.  I would describe the dialogue as 14-year-old humor that harps on many RPG tropes.  The writers clearly have a sense of humor, which is nice.  The (side)quests are about a 4/10, really only designed to have you revisit old areas.  Some of them have unique bosses, those are cool.The gameplay is also about 8/10, very tight controls.  I really only played 2H with a few extra spells, but the game will allow you to play archer, sword n board, 2h, or a mage in any/all of 4 magic schools.  Plus, there are support spells that help both melee and caster.  The spells seem really weak at low level but quite good once "leveled up."  Points can be re-allocated for gold, which is great because you can try something for a price.  Cons: Not much content yet, but it is still a solid stable and polished beta build.  If they keep creating more of the same, this game will be a fantastic modern version of its predecessors like Secret of Mana/Evermore, Link 2 tha Past and others.

content:
Posted: March 25
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								This game was an extreme disappointment. My friend and I had been looking forward to this game for months and when my friend bought it for me as a surprise I was ecstatic. Now all I feel is guilt that they paid money on this unfinished garbage and am hoping the refund goes through.The game seemed beautiful, but how this game looks in gameplay videos and the trailer is incredibly decieving. Don't let it fool you- there's only a few hours of story content here, and not even good story at that. You won't be getting much out of this game other than the pretty visuals, and there are plenty of much better pixel art games out there that you could buy.While playing through with my friend we encountered multiple glitches that made the game unplayable or forced us to close it in order to get out of a never-ending loop of glitches. The storyline is nowhere near finished and hasn't been updated in months (if it ever plans to be finished). Don't even get me started on the rougelike. (It's not fun in the slightest and just seems like a shoddy thrown together attempt to make the buyers stop complaining about lack of content)Overall the best description of this game is soulless. It felt like it was made for the purpose of enticing people to pay more money than what the minimal amount of content is worth, It looks appealing to the eyes, but has no replayability and runs out of content incredibly quickly. This game is not and will never be worth 15 dollars in it's unfinished state, and it says directly on their dev blog they never plan to put it on sale  until it is finished, and I feel like there's a better reason for that than the shoddy one that the dev blog claims. As evidenced by the amount of content that has been put out in the past two years, they seem to be putting out the minimal amount of content to give the buyers hope that this game isn't completely abandoned.Don't purchase this game. You'll regret it and be hoping for a refund like I am.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2016
Early Access Review
								Only giving a thumbs down because there are only the binary options, otherwise I'd get like a 7/10.  On the whole it is a good game, but not what I wanted.  Gonna be a bit negative, but know that if the game's name caught your attention than you should not be dissapointed.  I've been living and breathing action RPGs for years.  Each Souls game? 100+ hours.  Each Monster Hunter?  700-1500+ hours.  Got this to fill in the drought between DS3 and MHG.If you are thinking about getting this because you like the more difficult and/or intricate action combat systems then you might want to pass.  Normal mode is far too easy, and the answer to hard mode is just "throw more sh*t in there."  With your character's sprite, your pet's sprite, any summons you have, and the gang bang of hostile targets it becomes a clusterf*ck of pixels.The problem is you only really have your shield to be defensive.  The angle is somewhat forgiving when you block, but blocking commits you to the direction until you drop your guard.  Add in that there are no defenses based on mobility (sprints, side/back steps, rolls, etc) and your perfect guard will be swiftly answered with a kick in the♥♥♥♥♥Not that this all matters anyway.  There is no penalty for death as of yet.  Takes some of the teeth out of a difficult game when there is no penalty for messing up.But in the end if you wanted to live the old days of the SNES action RPG then by all means get it.  Don't let a grumpy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like me change your mind.

content:
Posted: April 11
Early Access Review
								Meh....This game is ok. Definitely overrated here on steam though.For one thing it's one of THEE most slow to develope games I have ever seen. Barely only faster then games like Starforge which quit development. If you buy this, don't expect a complete game for at least 20 years. Don't be surprised if they never properly finish either (rushed content). STANDARD ISSUE JRPG STORY?I don't personally care for the story much, and the gameplay is extremely repetitive (go into field, whack the mobs, repeat). OTHER GAME MECHANICS?They added all sorts of things to do like fishing and crafting but non of these extra things are well designed nor very fun.Fishing is annoying to do, trying to keep a small area lined up on a moving line or you lose the fish, and it's very unforgiving if catching a big fish. Probably the most uninteresting way to add fishing, even more boring then how ARK does it *quick time events*Crafting is structured in a way so that you never get higher level tier materials. You will only ever find CURRENT story progress relevant level materials, ensuring you can only ever make gear that is almost identicle in stats to what can be purchased at the store, or found as loot. There is no way to get future gear that makes current dungeons easier. Great, but, SO WHY HAVE CRAFTING THEN? IT doesn't do anything else and feels so hopelessly tacked on. It isn't even interesting in HOW you craft. Just get the mats, hit a button, done. You don't harvest resources either, the mats are just from killing monsters. Seriously this crafting system is here only so they can brag about having a crafting system to sucker people into buying this ho hum game. =3BOSSY!The boss fights are intense, and the only hard part unless you don't take time to grind for a while (Note I played on hardest)- you need to be a master at not stepping into the fire, and gear\stats is secondary in importance. Expect to die die die die die over and over again trying to learn some of these fights, especially WINTER boss. Hard mode will definitely not be for everyone here.The music was fair.The art is really high quality.Controls are fluid.My butt is acid.erm...What else am I forgetting?The roguelike mode was a HUUUUUUUUUUUGE disappointment. It isn't some random dungeons like your favorite roguelike game with exploration, oh no, it's more like playing smash TV with each room being a small arena and a few mobs to kill so the door to the next room unlocks. It's the near same thing everytime, same mobs, same pretty much everything. The only fun thing about it, is unlocking new shops and stuff in town to help future playthroughs not be as boring (hopefully).The Secrets of Grindea are not much of a secret, and this game is only some small bits of fun to me. But this isn't exactly my bag baby, what with secret of mana not being amazing to me either. That is the game this is most similar to from the past I'd say, and most people will adore this game as the very high steam rating can show you.I recommend it, only because I know everyone is less jaded then me on games like this! But seriously dev team, finish it sometimes this decade please!

content:
Posted: April 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Okay, so I've reached the end of the Beta. Figured I'd give my input.For $14.99, it was fun while it lasted, but waaay too short as you could reach the final area before you're stopped by an NPC that tells you you've reached the end of the Beta.So far I'm Lvl 20, and though I did most the side quests (only have like 3 left), there isn't much else to do other than grind and collect stuff, which is repetitive and tedious. Then again, that's what you gotta expect from a game called Secrets of Grindea, and playing the role of a "Collector" as they are called in this game.Not saying it's a bad game, it was fun, and it's more fun and challenging if you have friends to play with, but aside from that, it seems fairly short for its current price, as the game is incomplete, and you have to wait for more of the story to be released to be able to continue.Because of this, I can not recommend this game, because I've seen games before that are early access, or incomplete, with a fairly moderate to high price, only to eventually not be completed at all, leaving us loyal consumers in the dust, and kicking ourselves for spending $14.99 on an incomplete game that may or may not be completed in the near future.I'll continue to play it, just so I can get all the cards, and farm some items while I wait. But until then, I wouldn't recommend this game until it is fully released, and when it is, I may change my recommendation then.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								Fantastic potential!  Above average story, fun, engaging script, and likable character tropes.  The visual style lends itself well to all aspects of the game.However, this is a game where combat is the bulk of play; in its current state combat is just a little too clunky for my liking to give this game a solid recommendation.  That being said, much of player control is surprisingly tight and responsive.  The problem is that there are too many zerg-rush rooms to let skillful control shine.  Anemic character reach is punctuated by punishing post-swing recovery, and the mobs of enemies ensure that, whether you hit your target or not, another enemy will likely be shooting you in the back during your recovery frames.  Shield-block input seems sluggish deciding between whether you told the character to strafe with the shield up or to change direction to block the sword about to slash your back open.  Perfect Guarding is just an absolute mess when 4+ enemies are wailing on you.I'm hopeful this will end up a gem of a game, but right now stay away unless you're interested in playtesting to contribute to its growth.

Early Access Review
								This game needs quite a bit of tweaking. After only 2 and a half hours of gameplay, not only have I had to restart the game from the begining, but I would have to do it again because half of the quests I do break if I exit and save only to come back the next day and find out that I apparentley I already did it even though the quest is still not done.Another issue I encountered was that when I saved on my first session playing this game and came back the next day, even though I had all my equipment, all of my quest and story progress had been lost. Pretty annoying if you ask me.My third and final issue that I found was that half the time while trying to run the game, instead of loading it up straight away like my other games, it wouldn't start up. So after clicking on the desktop icon a couple times, it finally loaded up but not properly. The game's resolution screwed up my screen size and zoomed in on a portion of my desktop in a lower quality without the game even loadind up fully. The taskbar icon for the game was active but the game itself wasn't running at all. It didn't even come up when I loaded task manager and tried to end task it. Manually closing it from the taskbar didn't help either. I tried to get a refund, but of course you can only get a refund for a game if you have UNDER 2 HOURS. Pretty dissapointed because not only could I have spent my hard earned cash on something else that would actually work, but I can't even get my money back.Overall, gameplay and fighting is kinda generic and well put together, but the amount of bugs in only 2 and a half hours is pretty horrendous.4/10P.S. The resolution screwing up when booting up the game may be just my fault because of the small resolution monitor that I play on, but come on:It's a laptop

number of helpful: 10 of 29 people (34%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								Apparently, from what I've been told and read, that this game has been in development for 5 years.I come back to the game a year after I beat the content of the game and all that's been added is a few pages of dialogue and a new "dungeon". Took me about an hour or so to bust through the new additions, then I spent some time in arcade mode.So... Let's do some simple maths ('Cause I don't know how to do much else concerning maths);~1 hour of story content = 1 year of development.Game looks to be about 30-50% "complete" in its story. Wouldn't be surprised if the devs skimped a bit just to release a "full product" in a few years.Let's take a look at, say Cave Story. Took a guy 5 years (during his spare time, also in college and working a full time job) to make this game. Game's a masterpiece in its genre. Polished and perfected.Let's also assume that the 3 devs (I dunno if they hired anyone else, doubt it though) are also on this same schedule. Spare time working on the game only. 5 x 365 = 1826. 1826 / 3 = 608.733333~That's just shy of 2 years in development for a completely finished product if 3 people are on the workload in an an equal capacity. So why has it taken 3 people 5 years to do the same amount of work as 1 guy? Why is the development of this game so slow and awful?I shall pose an answer for you in the form of a question; Say you pay someone upfront, the full price of the cost to put a roof on your house. What is the motivation to actually do the work? What's stopping this company from driving in a single nail per day and then calling it quits? They already have your money, why continue with the job at all?Early Access is just... A bad business model in its current form. It's not bad for the business, that's for sure, as games like Starbound and this one will attest to. It's bad for the consumer, and for some reason the consumer just laps this garbage up like it's some sort of ambrosian nectar of the dev-gods. There really needs to be some sort of time-limit (One year at the most, 30 days after the deadline to clean up) for games to either finish their development and release a full product, or start refunding all purchases completely.As it stands, there's absolutely no reason for anyone to ever pull "Early Access Game" from their pages it's basically free money for a tech demo and a couple of lines of "story" to sate the spasms of frothing, ADD-rattled fans.Gaming has fallen so far, and I hope for another crash.

								Here's the summation as quickly as i can:  This game COULD be amazing.  But it feels... like a lacunae.  There is just this huge hole in the gooey center where the peanut butter should be.  With some skill fine tuning, additions of more skills (because even for a nostalgic ARPG this is really light on what you can do besides mix and match) perhaps this game could be a buy.  I bought 3 copies of this for myself and 2 friends... and let me tell you.  That was a dissapointment.  This game MIGHT end up a gem, but for now?  This gem needs a roll in the rock tumbler.  PS.  Fix your combat skills.  As smooth as the movement is, the skills feel like you have to touch the enemy to land half of them.  Also: in multiplayer health orbs not only are actually hard to pickup due to the 1 mm hit detection, but they arent shared with the team.  thumbs up on boss fights though.  for instance, in the first dungeon I really enjoy how you presented them.  even if your gear is such dogsh*t that if you get hit a few times you get dropped.  button mashing won them... not skill placement

Early Access Review
								I was so thrilled. So many great skills, items, quests. The artwork was great, the game was wonderful. But this isn't Early Access. The game is just plain unfinished. So much potential, and it's still on the works, and it has been so for a while (not apparent from the Steam release date, but the project has been going on before that for a couple of years). Wait and see if it is completed, someday.

number of helpful: 5 of 45 people (11%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Its a really well done game, but the current state its in, I recommend waiting before purchasing it. Its not done and some parts of the game feel a bit out of place with the crafting system being hard to come by or just boring grinding. Boss fights are amazing and one of the best parts of the game but is one of the only good parts to look foward to in this game. The leveling up system feels out of place and I know that the devs wanted a game where you can do anything you want with no class or items that truly make you different with others but honeslty that what makes a good RPG or even games with simular things like WoW, Fallout, Skyrim and etc, hell even Terraria does it well. So many times me and my friends found items that were just better that what we had already so having no other choice we use it hoping maybe it will help us. With No Classes thier no reason to build up to a certain classes or benifits really because at times it seems like your character is no different then the other people who play this because everyone justs goes for something thats good and only the good moves and perks making it kinda pointless when just everyone gets the same♥♥♥♥♥♥ taking the varity out of the game and really nothing to say" I made this character to my play style or even a cool build". Money is also Pointless at times and just used to buy junk at the blacksmith because you dont wanna grind or dont even know about the bad crafting system in the game. The crafting system is never really introduce and its just there at times not really showing you anything about it or some of the cool items you can make. Two choices that best describe the crafting system is thats it there use it or don't because you will probly forget about it or don't care.Story is good, fun and amazing but at times its like left 4 dead, by just walking from point A to point B making it really boring along with the never ending spawning of enemies that just are annoying as hell at times.This game brings alot of cool elements and amazing coop gameplay that just make it feel right. I truly want to play this game more but theres nothing atm ( AND THE GAMES NOT DONE ) that makes me want to come back with buddies and play. Its a great adventure but with mechanics that don't feel right but is not afriad to try something new but Im just not sure if it fits the game while this game trys to be more than one genre and even then it hardly fits them. Its a decent game and I see alot of potenial in this and wish that other games took risk with like this at times.

								Okay, so my time says 2.2 hours, mostly for the case because it does'nt count offline time... BUT i still think being that i've gotten pretty dang far, i think i should have a say, before i start, these are simply my pros and cons upon the game, you like them, great! if not, well prefernaces are preferances! now let's get started!Pros:-Old fashion RPG style, i think it's refreshing to see old styles coming back, not lazily done either, this was actually made as such with care, sure it's a work in progress or "Early Access", BUT so far, can't complain too much about the game style.-graphic style, i'm not usually one for 2d pixle style unless it's either done well, or turns out like terraria, where the gameplay makes up for it (My opinion... besides, you can make you're own texture packs for terraria anyways...), but game however, has done it correctly in my opinion, given it that charm that i don't get from most games now a days.-skills, sure alot of them are'nt that "Uniqe", but they are pretty good, concidering you can dash foward and damage anything in the way? or leap back and slash foward? i can't complain that much!-Cards, this is actually better then you may think, No it's not part of a card game, but their permanent boost to a certain stat, or additional damage or special ability, plenty a pain to gain, but pretty good otherwise.-Crafting, not much at the moment, but i can see this going pretty well if done well.-Costume slot, Has to be said, considering i can have a full plate helm and still look like i just have glasses on, basically making my own appearance in the game? gotta say, THIS i really like...-Pets, Gotta say, i like pet's as is, but just having a jack o lantern as an option? that won me over for that detail, but to the real stuff, basically feeding you're pets, you give the xp in a certain stat, once it levels, it gives you a bonus for as long as you have the pet! (Seriosely though, Devs, Great job on the jumpkin pet, Love it, Love it, LOVE, IT...)now the cons (Note: i don't have too many because the rest are mostly one nuetrals):-YES the game is very grind-ish at times, gaining materials, certain armors, weapons, I'm just placing this here because even I have to admit that this CAN get mind numbing, BUT take note: This one is least concerning, why? The word "Grind" is in the title, so really... well that IS what you're getting a peice of... but to be fair, you don't HAVE to grind to get through the story, again, don't pay TOO much attention to this one.Now the Nuetrals:_Custimization: Yes i do like the costume feature, and yes i can basically make myself in real rife... for the most part, still missing facial hair, but we are playing as a young child... my point in this one is, Yes it's there, just not much of it is there at this time, which the reason it's a nuetral? "Early access" is why.-Armor, and when i say this one, i mostly mean chest armor appearance, basxically... it never changes, no form of changing it accept colors, i guess you could say this is SORT of a request, but a deal breaker by any means, Just a small request to let us change from simple shirt and scarf to say leather or metal armor? to appropriate to the class? robesx for mages, leather for rogues, metal for tanks? mostly for appearance, like in costumes...-Difficulty, i don't mean for the common enemies, i just mean for certain bosses it CAN be rather... unforgiving... until you find some form of work around or loopole to the boss...That's about it really, again, the game is early access, so not TOO much can be said upon it quite yet, it does look promising so far, heck, if i had friends or people to play with, or someone to help get through the story, i'de go for i9t to be honest, but any ways,  at the current time, i would give this game... 7.5/10 seem fair? for it's current status, this is in no way the final grade, but yeah for those who just want a charming, nice, Mostly friendly game to play, i recommend this plenty!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Zelda meets Terraria.At least, that's how I'd view it.  The graphics are very good and well animated (for a 3 person team, from what I've heard!).  But that's probably not what you want to hear; you probably want to hear about the gameplay.The attacks are very satisfying, going up two types of charges: silver and gold.  And if you don't like your build, you can use money to reset it, which is very nice.  You're not restricted by classes either, so you can switch freely.  What's better than hitting the (current) last dungeon and ohko'ing everything with your 2h weapon and a crit build?  Probably a billion dollars but if I'm trying to convince you to buy this game, you probably don't have a billion dollars.  Sorry.The story is quirky and cute, and the puzzles are pretty easy so it's not hard to get by the story.  The references are great too.  And if the story's not enough for you, but you don't want to do arcade mode, there's always the grind (for loot and cards)!Arcade mode is quite a challenge (at least for me and my trio of inept friends.  Oh god, the bees) but it's fun and so far seeing the perks and trying to get town upgrades motivates me to keep trying. (We've made it to the second floor.  A true display of skill.)However, some things I'm not so keen on, such as:- Bows.  Do you even really need them? (except for that one area that I won't spoil)  I was doing 1.1k+ damage with a 2h weapon on a crit, but only 255 damage on an arrow crit.  Not to mention that the ammo is limited.  I would like for there be a more traditional ranged weapon class, so I'm hoping that later editions will introduce stronger bows, perhaps.- For some reason the hair stylist sometimes glitches out and the previews of the hair icons are all glitched.- Leveling pets is a bigger grind than I thought it'd be, but it's probably because higher level food drops haven't been implemented yet (I'm hoping.  Oh god 1000 apples no why).- Marino needs to be stopped.  I hope the devs write in a side quest for this.  Thanks.- CHICKEN HERDINGI'm very much looking forward to future updates and the full release of the game!  And if you're still interested, but on the fence, try out the free demo!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 19, 2015
Early Access Review
								PERMANENT BETAPERMANENT BETAYesterday Planetary Annihilation released a standalone game that completely replaces their older product. The game was successfully Kickstarted and went through Early Access where it attracted endless negative reviews; missing features, promises that weren't kept and deadlines that weren't met. The cynical among us might suggest a completely new product means a fresh slate for Steam reviews - but it's a damning indictment of a company's misuse of Early Access.It's a shame because, for the most part, Early Access has been a phenomenon, allowing games to grow and developers to get real feedback on what's working and what isn't and make changes based on those player responses. Secrets of Grindea has recently hit the Early Access scene and, after a successful demo launch earlier in the year, stands out as a shining example of development done right.Secrets of Grindea is a 2D RPG in the vein of the older Zelda or 'Of Mana' titles. it has the same charming art style but has a quality of animation that gives the whole game a modern feel, that unfortunately doesn't translate especially well into screenshots. The game focuses on a young boy leaving his village to become a man (stop me if you've heard this one before) and to do so he must first collect his sword and shield and make his way to the nearest town.On the way you'll learn the basics of combat and get a real feel for how exceptionally well animated Secrets of Grindea is. The sway of a cloak as you dash, the hunched shoulders of a defensive position and the theatrical swirl as human enemies pirouette to the ground in defeat.The premise of the game is, aside from killing and leveling up, that you are a collector. A type of champion who's tasked with chronicling and cataloging things within Grindea's gorgeous and vibrant world. There's a hint of Pokemon about it all, but Secrets of Grindea wears its influences proudly; and why not? This is an excellent reimagining of some classic ideas and franchises.The levelling up system itself is more reminiscent of Diablo than any other franchise. As you level up you get skill points which you can put into various areas; magic, defense, skills etc You can unlock new, castable abilities which subsequent points will improve, or level up several of your passive skills. It's adequate, though I'm yet to come across a level up system that I could ever describe as anything other.I've finished all the content available in Secrets of Grindea's Early Access build outside of the game's Arcade Mode which I'll delve into when the full release arrives. As it stands, though, I would have no reservations about recommending Secrets of Grindea to anyone. It's been a while since a game has been so whimsical, light-hearted and, as simple as it sounds, fun. It's gorgeous, colourful with a stellar soundtrack and is more than an homage to 16 bit classics. This is a faithful re-imagining of the tropes of old with a modern shine and it does it so much better than everyone else. http://www.permanent-beta.net/previews/2015/8/19/early-access-investigations-secrets-of-grindea

								This game was purchased to me by a friend, we played it together. It's (as the name suggests) kinda grind reliant, the grinding itself is pretty fun though! Monsters/enemies are well-made. Good aesthetics, not too easy and not too difficult. There's plenty of secrets and tricks to discover as well.The crafting system is actually pretty decent, it's quite easy to figure out, though there's no information saying "item dropped by X" - You kinda have to remember which enemy drops what, but the names are quite relatable!I've played it solo as well and can be fun, but I think with good company it's more enjoyable, although you'll have to fight for loot haha! (loot settings can be altered by host)I'd recommend this game if you like exploring and crafting. Not to mention the art style is incredibly cute :) (reminds me of Maple Story)

content:
Posted: October 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								If you have a friend you really like playing with online, I really cant say anything else than WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR? This game is wonderful, the combat is beautiful, the music is awesome, and the humour put into it actually wants you to read the text and kinda follow the plot, I was really sceptic to this game when we started and then you start to get the feel of the game.We ended up finishing the story mode that's currently out as it is early access still, and we've sat for about 8 hours if not more. The combat is very satisfying, especially with controller, I havent tried with mouse and keyboard, but with controller everything is smooth and awesome. The bossbattles are extremely wild and incredibly satisfying when you win, the battles are quite hard on normal difficulity, and when you die you dont really feel cheated or that anything is unfair, you just kinda laugh and get back at it. The graphics are a perfect 10/10 for the type of game it wants to be. beautiful particle effects, and animations. Some of the characters you meet are quite memorable, because of their attitude, or just humour. If you want something to play by yourself or with up to 4 friends , thats smooth, fun, challanging, and awesome, then this is the perfect game, and its not that expensive. I really reccommend this game even tho on the screenshots and video it might not look that extraordinary, but trust me, its fantastic. 9.5/10 from me.

								Man I feel dumb.I Was told this game had straight up multiplayer, like just joining others in groups and so on without having friends who own the game.I guess I should have read the description first, its just the idea of a secret of mana like game with a nice controller support was excellent, but as a single player game I'd rather be playing mana.PROS: Excellent skills and abilities system. Simple and effective gearing system, nostalgic feel, cool areas.CONS: this game could be really fun if it had an online multiplayer player matcher or something, just something that can put players with eachother when they are roughly the same level and progress in the game, this would give a sense of community within the game. I'm not great with puzzles, so I've given up at a few points to go play arcade.

content:

Early Access Review
								It kept me playing because of the difficult (on hard mode) combat coupled with smooth controls and a decent number of viable gear+skill builds.  Not much story, but what is there can be pretty funny.  Devs are still very active, and post weekly updates on their website (which eventually make their way into the stable build).  I spent most of these hours playing single player campaign, just messing around with every build I could think of.  The arcade mode is also a great challenge.  Both modes can be played with friends (although I have only played solo).  Even if (and this seems unlikely) they stopped developement, I would say I have already gotten my money's worth.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
Early Access Review
A blend of scott pilgrim and Diablo 2Note: This entire review is from playing story mode by myself. I haven't tried multiplayer and arcade mode I've only tried a small amount, so realize this isn't the most complete review.Pros:The game has an action rpg feel with it's talent trees and skills that is like diablo 2/torch light. There's alot of depth here for you to customize your hero into a full warrior or a mage or a hybrid of the two. The retro look makes it seem easier to pick upAs you go deeper into the game the boss fights become more challenging, to the point where I can almost guarantee that you'll die by the 4th or 5th bossThere's a crafting system that reminds me of dragonquest XIII, it's pretty dope. You take misc. items and you combine them to form stronger swords, shields, etc.Cons:The story seems like a parody of other games, many bosses are references to old games and anime like a gundam boss and things similar. And the title of the game itself, Secrets of "Grindea", is a reference to grinding, or hours of constantly doing monotonous tasks in mmorpgs in order to get something. Many of the cities like EverGrind are references like this too. You can definitely see where the creators drew inspiration and they take alot of time to give nod to that but I also wish that they'd take their own story and lore a bit more serious. Admittedly I haven't really taken the time to read much of the chat boxes but that's the impression I get from some of the bosses and atmosphere. Some of the spells feel lackluster at first and I find myself constantly respeccing my hero.Would I recommend it?I would to someone who's already a fan of a scott pilgrim beat em up or like diablo 2/torchlight type of action rpg or someone who's into games like the older zelda games like link to the past. For $6-$10 I think this game is well worth the price. There are promised updates with more dungeons in the future which I'm really looking forward to. I'm only level 13-14 at the time of this review and not even close to finishing all of the content, there's definitely enough content and grinding to keep a player in the game until updates arrive.

Early Access Review
								**Edit** The game has been updated to now fix the save file deletion issue I had. As this was my only reason for saying "no - not in the current state" I have now changed it to a positive review (as it always was if fully read). Cheers!Great game, but not recomending it in its current state. Played for 4-5 hours with 2 others, my girlfriend was the host. Alt-tabbed to activate skype and both myself and the other guy we were playing with crashed and lost our characters. Not in the select screen.. simply gone. I would recommend supporting the game as we had a lot of fun whilst it lasted, with funny dialogue and a promising talent/combat system like a modernized zelda title. If you don't mind the potential loss of character in multiplayer, or you are a fan of hardcore rogue-like, feel free to play now :)

content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
Early Access Review
								Great little RPG that can give you quite a bit of fun and a lot of hours of gameplay. The combat is very good, fluid and doesn't make you "get caught in animation" with that said, you can miss attacks if not facing the same way as the enemy. This can make things a bit difficult in tight spots, however the blocking system works really well.All in all this game is great, you wont regret buying it, full price or on sale (which I have yet to see it do) however I have one caution for any buyer....****DO NOT BUY THIS ON STEAM!********You're missing out on a free DRM free copy!! Thats right, if you buy this here you don't have access to the DRM free copy, but if you buy it through either Secrets of Grindea's website, or on Humble Bundle's site they give you access to both the Steam key and a DRM free copy! So DO NOT BUY HERE! Or you're forced to miss out on that free copy. Hope you find as much fun in this little title as I have.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Secrets of Grindea is a great game.  Love the old school nostalgic feel of it and it's simplicity.   The graphics of the game are exactly where they need to be for this type of game which is what drew me to it.  I also love the fact that your characters and their skill sets are completely customizable, making the game an ever changing adventure for the players.  I played as a battle summoner, as well as a mage. :D  Another thing I love about it is that you can use a keyboard or gamepad which for me made things a lot easier.  This game is well suited for a gamepad.  The only complaint that I have is that I wish they would get more content out there for us so I can play the rest of the game. :)   I don't mind playing the rogue-like arcade mode, but would much rather finish the storyline within the game.  Been wanting to do an online run with some people and make some new friends so feel free to add me if you want to. Overall I would give the game 4.5 stars out 5 rating.  Once the game is finished I more than likely with give it a 5 out of 5. Great Job Devs, and keep up the good work.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								With 11 hours into the game, I am still looking forward to playing more. While this game is technically in early access (beta), a lot of the important stuff is polished; and the portions of the game that still need work haven't caused any problems (so far as I can tell). I'm very much looking forward to the additions soon to come and the developers are hard at work on the game with the updates remaining constant. What appears to be the most important aspect of this games early success, though, is the games ability to capture my attention for long periods of time; and want more when I'm not playing. I know that I will be sinking many more hours of my life into this game and I highly recommend this game to any action RPG fan. It will keep you glued to your computer for hours.

Early Access Review
								Instant love. Gorgeously animated, and well executed and tight gameplay. The story and setting pokes fun at the genre. It is quite charming, and delivered at an appropriate fast pace. Lots of skills and specializations seem to indicate repeated plays if you wish, but there doesn't seem to be any random maps. Game's biggest weakpoint are the backgrounds, which are very crudely drawn in places.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								Secrets of Grindea is a great game.  Love the old school nostalgic feel of it and it's simplicity.   The graphics of the game are exactly where they need to be for this type of game which is what drew me to it.  I also love the fact that your characters and their skill sets are completely customizable, making the game an ever changing adventure for the players.  I played as a battle summoner, as well as a mage. :D  Another thing I love about it is that you can use a keyboard or gamepad which for me made things a lot easier.  This game is well suited for a gamepad.  The only complaint that I have is that I wish they would get more content out there for us so I can play the rest of the game. :)   I don't mind playing the rogue-like arcade mode, but would much rather finish the storyline within the game.  Been wanting to do an online run with some people and make some new friends so feel free to add me if you want to. Overall I would give the game 4.5 stars out 5 rating.  Once the game is finished I more than likely with give it a 5 out of 5. Great Job Devs, and keep up the good work.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								Secrets of Grindea is an over-head 16-bit style RPG. It implements features like skills that you can upgrade, which allows you to choose what role your character takes (Melee or magic, or both). The devs seemed to focus more on mechanics and gameplay rather than storyline. But, it's not all hack-and-slash, there are puzzles through out the game, some that you have to complete, some not. The combat is good in-that you can't just spam the attact button since that'll probably get you hit, the game kind of forces you to utilise skills that you've chosen when in combat, which is a good thing because it keeps the player on their toes and makes them think about what their next move will be. Overall, I'd recommend it to anyone who likes these sort of games and not just games like CoD and CS:GO and even though the game's in beta, it feels like a completed game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 10, 2016
Early Access Review
								Have you ever wondered what a Zelda game with Terraria aspects to it would be? Well, the Secrets of Grindea is basically that, but better. SOG as I call it, starts as you as the silent protagonist in the world of Grindea, a fantasy world with a main story, and a bunch of side quests. This game is yet another early access game, but there is a ton to do here, just in the Beta version. There are 2 main modes so far. There's the main story campain, that you can eather play alone or with friends   online on a co op game. And there's Arcade Mode where you and friends can go through dungeons, collect treasure, weapons, do challenges, and kill enemies, to see how far you get. If you die you start over, so you have to do it all again, but  you can get escence statues, that you can use to purchase upgrades, to give you an easier time. Honestly, I think it's annoying sometimes, starting all over each time, but it's still fun regardless.SOG is a very good game, and I absolutely love it, even in Beta, and I can't wait to see what the full game will be like! It's fun with friends, and great alone.  For $15 I still think it's worth the price, and I usually don't think that for other early access games. The Secrets of Grindea gets a 9.5/10

content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Interested? Read This First!ContentIt really depends on how you play it. I lke to call myself a beta tester even though im not and i dedicated my time to try and collect all items. Still havent done it though and ive put nearly 50 hours into the game. If you are a person who likes to collect things, try to find interesting exploits and glitches, then the game is perfect for you if you put it on frontline. If you are a hardcore speed runner, the game is still good for you even if it isnt on frontline as the arcade mode has infinate replay value and you could try and give yourself a challenge by putting the story mode on hardmode. However if you are a person that gets disinterested in things very quickly, this game is fun but not the best for you. UpdatesIf you put the game on frontline you will get very frequent game changes, update ideas, bug fixes, and other things that will have you able to play the game over and over to see what they changes and how it affects the game. For regular/non-frontline updates, you will see updates every so often, sometimes quicker than you think, but not as frequent as frontliners.Max levelThere isnt a max level and i would know becuase most are levels 30-40 while im level 35000 something. No joke.If you need any more info on the game just send me a message.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2016
Product received for free
Early Access Review
								This is a very well-made game, even though it's still in Early Access! I'm excited for every patch, and I love the passion put into this.I reccomend keyboard controls with it, but those get complicated after a while if you put in a LOT of spells, as is the same with using a controller.Overall, I highly reccomend this to play with some friends, especially in Story Mode! Arcade mode is just a simple, yet extremely difficult-as-it-goes kind of endless dungeon deal. You can upgrade your town(Called Arcadia) and get styles and items that can carry over to Story Mode!(My favorite has to be the Cat Ears and the Butterflies :D)The pixel art is amazing, the story is pretty funny, the characters are quite amazing, and overall it's great in my opinion! There's probably quite a few flaws, but I've yet to see any. Probably due to the rose-colored glasses I bear to these kind of games.Rating: 10/10!
